We’re beyond excited for Glee’s season premiere tonight, but we’re even more excited about some of the things Glee supports. Marriage equality is one of the many aspects of equality that the Harry Potter Alliance fights for. Part of the money we raised in our first ever Equality FTW fundraiser last year went towards a phone banking initiative where we made 3,000 calls and helped make marriage equality in Maine happen!

It wasn’t our first show of support for the cause and it won’t be our last, but we need your help to keep fighting! Our goal for our second annual Equality FTW fundraiser is $100,000 and - get this - we’re already over halfway there!

Our awesome partners - including Team Starkid - have been an amazing help in providing some (totally) awesome perks, but the donations come from everybody. If you want to help us fund another year of fighting for equality, please check out our Indiegogo page and consider donating: http://bit.ly/EFTW13

Have you joined S.P.E.W. (the Society for the Promotion of Equality Winning) yet? By being our sonorous charm, you can help spread the word about Equality FTW! We'll also send you something cool in the mail (by owl, of course). Check it out: http://thehpalliance.org/spew

"When it comes down to it, is there a hard line between want and need? You might think that need is just the basics. Food, water, warmth, air, but you haven’t had most of a century to think about it. When you need a bath, do you really need a bath? No, you might say, you want a bath. A lack of a bath isn’t going to kill you. Your ever-increasing stink and the bits of grit behind your ear aren’t going to come to life and strangle you in the night. So, you would argue, you want a bath, you don’t need it. 

I disagree. You need a bath because polite society (these days at least) expects it of you. There’s a need here, not to be clean, but to be a part. Because witches and wizards are humans, and humans need to be part of a larger whole. If you disagree with me, that is your right, but I may be the world’s foremost expert on need, so it is extremely likely that you are wrong. 

At Hogwarts, the basic needs haven’t changed too much in the last eighty years. The need for the loo has always been and remains the most common. The need for a hiding spot, for a clinic, a classroom, for the occasional soft corner for a couple that might not feel safe together elsewhere. Of the needs I have served, that is my favorite by far. Though helping a certain group of young witches and wizards find something that had long burned a hole in my consciousness was a wonderful moment, slaking the needs of love is the most rewarding." - an except from Hank Green's "The Womb of Requirement"

message:
Read Andrew Slack's HPA origin story:

"Today, on our eighth birthday, I feel so incredibly proud of everything we’ve achieved. Our Equality FTW fundraiser is $16,000 over our goal, and we still have two more days to campaign. Our mission has been endorsed and embraced by thousands of fans, educational foundations, movie studios, and partners like Evanna Lynch, Patrick Rothfuss, John and Hank Green, and Jo Rowling herself.

"Together we have sent five cargo planes full of medical supplies to Haiti (each named after a different Harry Potter character), donated over 70,000 books across the world, started substantially transforming education, began a constructive dialogue with the CEO of Warner Brothers to make all Harry Potter chocolate Fair Trade, and made significant strides for the LGBTQ, anti-genocide, and media reform movements.

"Right now, though, I want to tell you a story. It’s a long story - as those close to me know, I love long stories - but it’s worth it. This is the story of the HPA. I’m working on compiling this story into a book, but for now, here’s an excerpt."

A Message on National Coming Out Day from our Executive Director Andrew Slack:

"I’ve never had to come out to my parents to tell them, “Mom and dad, I’m heterosexual.” 

Or: 'Mom and dad, I’m a man.'

Everyone assumes that I must be heterosexual because I’m a man. And everyone assumes that I’m a man because my sex is male.

Secretly, I’ve had doubts. Boys used to call me 'gay' because I loved musicals and 'a girl' because I wasn’t good at sports (for some mutated reason it was assumed that sports are just for boys).

But any way, sometimes I’d question myself, 'what if these bullies really are right? what if  I really am gay?' or 'what if I really am a girl? '

It wasn’t a pleasant experience to be told I’m something that I’m not, but I’m grateful that I had it. Because it opened my eyes early on to how easy I had it compared to my friends who actually are not heterosexual. Later on, it helped open my eyes to how easy I had it compared to my friends who are trans.

And it’s helped me realize that all these gender norms and sexuality norms are mainly rules that our Muggle Minded culture tells us we need to follow. That way we can be like the Dursleys and be perfectly normal thank you very much.

Well, I’m not perfectly normal. I’ve never been perfectly normal. And I don’t want to be perfectly normal. Forget Muggle Games. I want Magic. I want to love and be loved fully as I am.

Everyone has that right. And today on National Coming Out Day, I hope that we can all lend our support and thoughts to those who struggle with coming out as lesbian, gay, bisexual, questioning, asexual, or in the case of gender identification, as trans. Or those who would rather just go with the term, 'queer' as a catch all phrase that takes back the persecution that 'non-straight' people have had to endure for so long.

I hope we can send our appreciation to those who have already come out but feel like, with every new job and every new friend they may have to come out again.

I hope we can just sit here in our full humanity and remember that we are beautiful, amazing, and miraculous just the way we are. And that whatever our sexual or our gender identification is, that it too is beautiful as it is.

There is no normal. Just the magic of love and the courage to act on it.

Happy National Coming Out Day."

Andrew Slack: "Hey everyone, I was just sitting around reflecting on our awesome 8th birthday. And I started thinking....when the HPA turns 11, we need to find a way to get it invited to Hogwarts. When it turns 13, we need to give it a giant Bar Mitzvah (so long as it studies hard on it's ve'havta and Torah portion) with a cool DJ and 17 year old dancers dressed in tacky clothes. 

When it's 16, we'll get it a permit and then a license. Of course at that point, I'm probably going to have to have "the talk" with the organization about being respectful, responsible, and safe. And I'm NOT LOOKING FORWARD to worrying about where it is all night!

But really, I'm hoping that our teenaged HPA is really into learning and Nerdfighting and watching John and Hank Green and being an HPA member. Because those teenagers are the best. Wait. This started off weird and clever and now it's just weird and meta."

This Halloween, we're proud to announce our new corporate sponsor, everyone's favorite magical treats manufacturer, Wizard Junk™!
Buy a Mr. Lovegoodbar today and get 15% off a subscription to the Quibbler with the code #WIZARDJUNK
Celebrate Halloween with Wizard Junk™! Available in Hogsmeade, Diagon Alley, and all fine wizard shoppes.
Our sponsor, Wizard Junk™, doesn't just manufacture chocolate. They also have a full line of magical sodas!

All of Wizard Junk™'s chocolate bars are certified Fairest Trade, which means all house elves and other magical workers who assisted in the production of the chocolate were paid fair wages. 

Wizard Junk™ was hesitant to switch to Fairest Trade practices, but their consumers insisted and, after realizing they could triple their profit margins by switching, they have become proud proponents of this basic act of human decency. Was there perhaps a cross-promotion deal with Fairest Trade that helped sweeten the decision? We're not saying no!
Happy #HPAlloween from young Hermione! Send us pics of your wizard costumes today and our sponsor, Wizard Junk™, might choose YOURS to share.

Annnnd the winner of the JK Rowling signed book contest is Dayna D., a public librarian whose entry about flobberworms won our madlibs contest. Check out her full madlib below and thanks to everyone who supported #EqualityFTW by entering the contest!

"Flobberworm (also known as the King of Can of Sodas)
M.O.M. Classification: XXXXX

The first recorded flobberworm was bred by Harry Freakin’ Potter, a jittery wizard and dentist, who discovered after much experimentation that a fizzing whizbee placed beneath a honey badger would produce a gigantic can of soda possessed of extraordinarily superfluous powers.
The flobberworm is a brilliant lime green can of soda that may reach up to fifty feet in length. The male has a bicycle helmet upon its head. It has gravely fervent fangs, but its most dangerous means of attack is the gaze of its large gold eyes. Anyone looking directly into these will suffer instant death.

If the food source is sufficient (the flobberworm will eat all mammals and birds and most corndogs), the can of soda may attain a very great age. Harry Freakin’ Potter’s flobberworm is believed to have lived for close on 64 months.

The creation of flobberworms has been illegal since medieval times, although the practice is easily concealed by simply removing the fizzing whizbee from beneath the honey badger when the Department for the Regulation and Control of Magical Creatures comes to call. However, since cans of soda are uncontrollable except by dentists, they are as dangerous to most jittery wizards as to anybody else, and there have been no recorded sightings of flobberworms in Western Canada for at least four hundred years."

story: The Harry Potter Alliance with Abby Christine Teasdale.

message: Andrew Slack: "I have now decided that I do not want to stop until President Obama does a 3 finger salute. Which means, you need to do one too. The first step in recovery is admitting that we have a problem and that we want to talk about that problem. That's the 3 finger salute. Have you made yours yet the main photo of your FB?"

Andrew Slack: I should clarify what I meant when I said that I want President Obama doing a 3 finger salute. If you are not aware, the HPA is running a Hunger Games-themed campaign called Odds In Our Favor. In the Hunger Games, the 3 finger salute is the symbol that we are in this together, to fight economic inequality.

We live in a country where 1% own 40% of the economy. Where 80% are forced to fight over scraps: just 7% of the economy. And yet President Snow's 1% continue to push for more cuts in life saving programs such as food stamps and unemployment benefits...much of these are needed because the 1% screwed up our economy with their recklessness. And after we bailed them out, they have moved to pushing us out of our homes.

1 in 5 children live in poverty, 1 in 6 Americans go hungry. The Districts are in poverty while the Capitol is partying.

But then there's us: fan activists who have proven that fantasy is not an escape from our world but an invitation to go deeper into it. We are going to go deeper into it and we are going to fight for 99% of this country in our Districts to be granted equality.

This is not a small moment. This is THE moment when we have a coalescence of an amazing campaign with an original message AND the entire world talking about the topic of that campaign. President Trumka of the ALF-CIO, the biggest coalition of unions in the world, has our back. 

I want every progressive organization in the country to use the three finger salute as THEIR symbol.

The 3 finger salute is admitting that we have a problem and that we are going to work on that problem together. The problem is economic inequality. 

It's the biggest problem in the United States. It is the only problem that's gotten worse every year since 1974. every other social issue has gotten better. NOT THIS ONE. This one is worse.

Dr. King was not assassinated until he changed his focus from race to class. Malcolm X was not assassinated until he changed his focus from race to class? And why did they change their focus? Because they realized that there would be no progress on race until we tackle class.

We must admit that we have a problem and that we are in this together. That is what we are doing. That is our three finger salute.

After we join together to blow this up, we are going to get every progressive leader who is for economic equality to do a three finger salute. Which means we need you to do this with us. 

This is it. We've been working for this moment when the HPA started on October 10, 2005. We're here. We've arrived with an amazing community that supports and loves each other, believes in the power of love, and is Internet savvy.

We have the power to change history. 

And we will not stop until the President of the United States joins us in it.

So can you join me in doing a 3 finger salute? Thank you so very much for being a community that has sent 5 cargo planes to Haiti, built libraries across the world, funded the protection of thousands of civilians in Darfur and Burma - helped pass marriage equality in Maine and Rhode Island - helped pass the Maryland Dream Act. Through Superman Is An Immigrant: helped work on immigration reform.

All equality issues. And now: the we join together in community with the 3 finger salute. Until the odds are in everyone's favor!!!!! Can you do it? Can you change your profile pic?

Let one of our volunteers, Claudia Morales, tell you why the you should consider supporting us in Project For Awesome: 

"Last year’s Project for Awesome helped fund what the HPA was able to accomplish in 2013. This included another successful Accio Books! drive, the continued fight for marriage equality, the Apparating Library, a kickass presence at two LeakyCons, a Superman-inspired stand for immigration reform, awesome new merch, and the ongoing Hunger Games campaign.

Even in the short time I’ve been with the HPA, I’ve seen it grow tremendously as a direct result of a ceaselessly generous, driven community. From HPA FTW to Equality FTW and everything in between, the organization is made possible by the people who support it.

One of my favorite things about this is that it’s not just donation-based. This is the first year I’ve been able to donate anything to any fundraising effort we’ve had, but I regard my participation from previous years as equally important. Votes, comments, and word of mouth are all vital; they’re also extremely accessible.

As 2014 approaches, I’ve been getting more and more excited to see what the new year has in store for the HPA. But there’s an order to things - in order for a “next year” to happen, we have to close out this year with one last big push, right? So here goes.

John and Hank have said it several times today, and they’ve said it before - the Project for Awesome is extraordinary not just in the good that drives it, but in the choice it gives the community. Every year, Nerdfighteria is given the opportunity to choose the charities that will receive a portion of the donations.

This makes the HPA’s opportunity to be one of the chosen recipients even more special, and I urge everybody to consider voting and spreading the word. No matter how much Harry Potter merch I buy and no matter how many times I visit the Wizarding World of Harry Potter in Orlando, nothing makes magic feel as real as this organization does. Nothing else is truer to the heart, message and vision of the story.

I’ve never come across anything as empowering, sincere, or moving as what we’ve accomplished in this community. I want nothing more than for it to continue. This is our chance to make that possible.

You can find all the videos made on the HPA’s behalf here. We’ve also compiled a post with the direct links to the voting page for each video here. It’s really just a matter of clicking the vote buttons and spreading the word. I’m not exaggerating when I say it would mean the world.

After all, it’s real for us.

DFTBA."

message: Thank you to each and every one of you for an amazing, awesome, totally rad, phantasmagorical 2013! We hope you had as much fun as we did. Have a safe and happy new year and we'll see you for more magic in 2014 ⚡️

2013 has been a huge year for the HPA. Please join us in our New Year celebration by donating three dollars by the stroke of midnight: http://thehpalliance.org/donate

Since the start of the year, we've raised our total number of book donations to communities in need to 120,000. 

--We now have 200 Chapters on five continents improving their local communities in the name of Harry Potter. 

--We were featured in the PBS documentary, "Is School Enough?" hailing us as a cutting edge model for engaging young people in learning outside the classroom.

--We have broadly expanded our campaign on corporate transparency regarding child slavery and collected over 200,000 signatures to send to Warner Bros. concerning their questionably-sourced chocolate frogs.

--With our Superman is An Immigrant campaign we collaborated with immigration reform leaders to begin changing the conversation on immigration.

--Everyone from Hank Green to major progressive organizers (like the AFL-CIO) are helping us take back the narrative of the Hunger Games story. With an op-ed in the LA Times and a campaign video with nearly a half-million views, we’ll keep going until the odds are in everyone’s favor.

--And just one of the many things to look forward to in 2014 is the Pearson Foundation working with us to put both Superman Is An Immigrant and Odds In Our Favor into public school curriculums.

These are no small feats and they all happen because of members like you. 

We're hoping that you can help make 2014 our best year ever at the HPA. If you believe in the power of stories to change the world, please invest in us with a small donation by midnight tonight: http://thehpalliance.org/donate
Source: http://nydailyrecord.com/blog/2013/01/07/commentary-poverty-a-trigger-for-gun-violence/#ixzz2jumIVFqS

message:
Some thoughts on love this Valentine's Day:

"Harry Potter teaches us what many great teachers have taught: love is the most ancient and powerful form of magic in our world. And like Harry, we have the capacity to love and this gives us a power that the Dark Lord knows not.

Love does not grab at others with hunger for approval and power. Love does not wish to bring any one down with it. Love is not narcissism. Love is not narrow. Love is expansive. Love does not control - it allows. It accepts. It cares. It blesses.

So love your friends, love your family, love Ginny and/or Hermione. 

Happy Valentine’s Day." - Andrew Slack

Watch this speech because Ellen Page is refreshingly self-aware, grateful, and eloquent about her relationship to the movement as an actress.

Watch this speech because a person who has struggled and prevailed so much is bravely letting you in.

Something to keep in mind this Oscars night. This graphic from Lee & Low drives home the often overlooked truth of a leading force in storytelling and entertainment. Film is a reflection and exploration of humanity; the Academy is obscuring the full picture. Change is long overdue.

"Is it true that you shouted at Professor Umbridge?"
“Yes,” said Harry.
“You called her a liar?”
“Yes.”
“You told her He Who Must Not Be Named is back?”
“Yes.”
Professor McGonagall sat down behind her desk, frowning at Harry. Then she said, “Have a biscuit, Potter.”
“Have – what?”
“Have a biscuit,” she repeated impatiently, indicating a tartan tin lying on top of one of the piles of papers on her desk. “And sit down.”

#IWD2014

Hank Green's "Accio Deathly Hallows" is a song that speaks to the enduring power of literature, our cultural need for story, and the magic that resides in our own hearts. 

Hank has performed the song in many different incarnations, each one independently gratifying, yet collectively failing to satiate the core needs of the Nerdfighting community: the need for an entire month to be dedicated to this singular musical triumph.

It is time.

Time for Hank Green to Vlog Accio Deathly Hallows Every Day in April.

message:
We got some really awful news yesterday and need your support more than ever.

We recently entered into a partnership with a popular book retailer to expand our "Books Turn Muggles Into Wizards" line of merchandise. But we received the final paperwork yesterday and look what it says! We're now contractually obligated to sell 100,000 pieces of "Books Turn Muggles Into LIZARDS" merchandise! 

We've been on the phone with both the retailers and our lawyers, but they're refusing to acknowledge a mistake and insist we stick to our contract as printed. 

Our only hope now is for us to show them the power of our members. PLEASE HELP US BY SIGNING THIS PETITION urging the book retailer, Laterstones, to let us out of our contract: http://dft.ba/-wizardsnotlizards

Sigh. Since we have to stick to our contract, here's what our t-shirts will all look like starting next week. If you don't want to see this happen, please sign the petition to let us out of the contract: http://dft.ba/-wizardsnotlizards #wizardsnotlizards

Since our contract says we have to market a Books Turn Muggles Into Lizards line, we thought it might help to expand the lizard theme to all of our merch.

We really don't want to have to produce this shirt though so please sign this petition urging the book retailers to let us out of this typo-ridden contract: http://dft.ba/-wizardsnotlizards #wizardsnotlizards #pizzalizard
We did a bad. Please help turn us back into wizards by signing this petition: http://dft.ba/-wizardsnotlizards #wizardsnotlizards
story: The Harry Potter Alliance updated their cover photo.

message:
Need treats for your reptile friends? Get some of our new Fair Trade Chocolate Flies!

Want the frogs back? Sign this petition: http://dft.ba/-wizardsnotlizards #wizardsnotlizards

One of our new lizard pals giving a Three Toe Pad Salute for #OddsInOurFavor. 

Turn us back into wizards: http://dft.ba/-wizardsnotlizards #wizardsnotlizards

Good news! Some Lizard Rock bands have agreed to help us promote our new line of lizarding merchandise. Founders of Lrock, Gecko & the Bunnymen, sing about all things reptilian. Their hit tracks include, "New Lizard Anthem," "I Am a Lizard," "Lizard Chess," and "The Weapon We Have Is Lizard." http://dft.ba/-wizardsnotlizards

The second Lizard Rock band to join our lizarding endeavors is The Komodo Dragons. You might've heard their hit songs, "Lizard Party Forever," "Lizard Rock Heart Throb," and "In Which Draco and Harry Secretly Want To Make Lizards." 

We're very grateful to have the help of these lrock bands during this tough time. If you want to help us out too, please sign this petition: http://dft.ba/-wizardsnotlizards

We are thrilled that Lizard Rock LEGEND, Iguana Pop, has reached out to us to support our effort! He is, of course, famous for "Lust For Lizards" and "I Wanna Be Your Lizard." This is truly incredible.

If you want to join Iguana Pop in supporting us in this time of crisis, please check out http://dft.ba/-wizardsnotlizards for more information.

Fantastic news! Over 800 of you supported us in our contract debacle and we’re happy to report that you made enough of a buzz to release us from our accidental commitment to sell one hundred thousand pieces of Books Turn Muggles Into Lizards merchandise. 

Thanks to you, we are wizards once more. It was a wild ride, but now the Harry Potter Alliance can return to being what it always has been: fanfiction written by Benedict Cumberbatch. #wizardsnotlizards

Spring is in the air (in some parts of the world...), and that can only mean one thing: It's time for #AccioBooks!

Over the years, our annual book drive has built libraries in Rwanda, the Mississippi Delta, and New York City. Members like you have collectively donated over 100,000 books. 

This year, we are thrilled to announce that our primary donation recipient will be the Brightmoor Community Center in Detroit, Michigan. All of the books collected during the drive will be catalogued by our University of Michigan chapter, the Whomping Wolverines, and in September they will be given away for free to members of the Brightmoor community during an appearance of our Apparating Library at Brightmoor's annual Back To School Rally.

You also have the option to donate locally or join up with your local chapter (http://thehpalliance.org/chapters/find-a-chapter) to see where they're donating this year. 

No matter how or where you donate books, be sure to log them for points in our annual House Cup: http://thehpalliance.org/accio-books-submission/

From our Executive Director Andrew Slack, on the 20th anniversary of the Rwandan genocide: 

"Today marks the 20th anniversary of the Rwandan genocide. When approximately 1 million innocent men, women, and children were killed in 100 days. An international community that was celebrating Schindler's List with a message of "Never Again" revealed itself to be more interested in film and less interested in life. The lessons of the Holocaust fell on deaf ears and the memory of the murdered were spat on as those with power and influence turned the other way in the face of well funded killing operations that are an evil beyond evil. Please take action below and show the people of Rwanda that we will not forget or abandon them in the future. 

And let us pause and remember the unbelievable reserves of courage, vision, mourning, and processes regarding peace, coexistence, and in some cases, forgiveness that Rwandans have employed these last 20 years.

And let us try and forgive ourselves for collectively allowing - actually, encouraging this genocide to have taken place (because when it did, Americans and our allies pulled out all forces and France made a fortune selling weapons to be used for the killings). This is not simply a day to remember when some Rwandans failed their friends and neighbors. This is a day when the entire international community failed to show the basic compassion necessary to live in a world that has even one iota of respect for justice, compassion itself, and love.

If we are to worship that mysterious force of love, we must remember and be held collectively accountable for the approximately one million who were killed and millions more who were intimately effected by one of the most heinous 100 days in human history. Rwandans are our brothers and sisters and we treated them in a way that is beneath the most elemental levels human decency. This is a day to remember. A day of tremendous sadness beyond sadness. A day that requires our collective society to listen to the voices from 20 years ago, calling for help. A day that requires us to listen to the survivors who lived through that period or were born from the wreckage of that time. And it is a day to remember our international obligation to understand that there is no us and them. Only us. Only us. Only us.

We must "love each other or perish." And in the name of all that is sacred and holy, let us choose love. For those in Rwanda and those Congolese who continue to suffer because of the genocide that occurred in Rwanda 20 years ago. Those Rwandan women who contracted HIV due to being gang raped during the genocide as adults, teens, or as young girls. For those in Darfur that our president and the president before him continue to ignore, spitting on the memory of those who were killed during the genocide 20 years ago. Those in the Nuba mountains suffering a similar fate to Darfuris from the same leader (Sudan's president Omar al-Bashir). Those all over our world from East Burma to Northern Uganda and on and on and on.

And for today and the next 100 days: we remember Rwanda's murdered and those who love them.

If humanity is to thrive or survive at all, we must take this moment and remember. Remember. Remember. We must mourn. And we must act. We must sing. And we must heal. We must cry. And we must smile. We must embrace each other. In short, must love each or perish. And let us remember Rwanda."

message:
Today is #EqualPayDay, marking how far into 2013 women had to work to earn what men did in 2012. The wage gap is the world's worst kept secret, with women and people of color earning less than white men in the same jobs. It is an issue at the very core of economic inequality.

Our Odds In Our Favor campaign has worked to bring such issues to light, prioritizing visibility and solidarity. We have collected your three-finger salutes at http://oddsinourfavor.org/ and documented varying aspects of economic inequality on http://wearethedistricts.tumblr.com/. Today and every day, we stand as advocates for economic equality.

Join us in observing Equal Pay Day by joining the discussion, following We Are the Districts, and posting your three-finger salutes in solidarity with all those affected by economic inequality.

message: Support literacy for everyone by getting involved in #AccioBooks http://thehpalliance.org/accio-books
story: The Harry Potter Alliance with Alondra Garcia Ramirez.

message:
In celebration of #AccioBooks, HPA members all over the world are unleashing their inner Hermione Granger and spreading the joy of reading. Since 2009, HPA members have helped build libraries in Rwanda, New York City, the Mississippi Delta, and Portland, OR. This year, we are bringing the magic to Detroit!

We are partnering with the Brightmoor Community Center and our University of Michigan chapter, the Whomping Wolverines, because low literacy is a major issue in Detroit. A little wand waving and a quick Google search leads curious witches and wizards to a mind-boggling statistic: 47% of Detroit residents qualify as “functionally illiterate” and struggle with reading, writing, speaking, and computational skills. Some have questioned whether the 47% statistic is accurate or timely (the original study was conducted in 1993), but most sources agree: low literacy levels are a major issue in Detroit. 

Being able to read and understand complex texts is what allowed Hermione to identify the monster hidden in the Chamber of Secrets and to uncover the truth behind Beedle the Bard’s children’s tales. In the muggle world, literacy is equally as important. Job seekers with low literacy skills struggle to find work and low-reading parents are often unable to help their children with school work. Researchers have even found that people with low literacy skills are more likely to wait until they are very sick to seek medical care and are less likely to participate in disease prevention activities, which contributes to rising healthcare costs. Overall, low literacy levels and the resulting complications are major contributors to economic inequality. When a huge portion of the population struggles to read a job application or understand a prescription label, it is clear that the odds are not in our favor.

Harry Potter fans know the difference a good book can make – and so do researchers. Studies show that early access to books can improve children’s reading habits, but schools and libraries in underprivileged communities have fewer books to go around. That’s where you come in. When you donate to the Apparating Library in the Brightmoor Community Center, you are putting more books into the eager hands of young Detroiters. Accio Books! is about more than giving away books. It is about spreading the power of story in communities that need it the most. Whether you donate one or one hundred books this year, you are adding a little more magic to the world. The more magic there is in the world – the more education and passion and creative solutions we cultivate – the closer we get to the day when the odds really are in everyone’s favor.

Books of all types can be mailed directly to:

The Apparating Library
℅ Brightmoor Community Center
14451 Burt Rd.
Detroit, MI 48223

And you can go to our website for more ways to get involved with Accio Books: http://thehpalliance.org/accio-books

=====

Sources at: http://thehpalliance.tumblr.com/post/83032259115/accio-books-bringing-magic-to-detroit

"From the time I found myself at home in that little segregated library in the South, all the way up until I walked up the steps of the New York City library, I always felt, in any town, if I can get to a library, I’ll be okay. It really helped me as a child, and that never left me. So I have a special place for every library, in my heart of hearts.”

This year's Accio Books campaign is almost over. It’s time for a final push. message:
"'The Fault in Our Stars' is at its core a love story between two teenagers. My sister never got to have a relationship like that. She got to experience just a few weeks of being 16. Witnessing a life and a romance she could have had made me feel unbearably sad and yet, oddly, uplifted. It’s as if, through Hazel, my sister is able to continue having new experiences. As if she got a sequel.

"I can vouch that my sister’s life was filled with other forms of love. Having a support group to bolster her, having an online community to socialize with, helped Esther to smile and press on. She was one of five siblings, all of us extremely close. (Whereas Hazel is an only child, texting below the dinner table while her parents carry on a conversation.) When John Green promised to make Esther Day videos for my sister’s birthday each year, she asked him to make the day about “family and love.” Esther encouraged us as a family to never hesitate to say “I love you,” to express ourselves honestly, to hug and laugh."

Esther Earl's sister, Evangeline, wrote an incredible article about Esther and The Fault in Our Stars for the Washington Post. The full story is linked below.

Our new campaign, the Esther Day Project, seeks to celebrate Esther's vision for a holiday about platonic love. Learn more and join in: http://estherday.org
Esther Day, our favorite holiday, is August 3rd. We're spending all summer getting ready. Learn more and join in: http://estherday.org

Granger Leadership Academy is the HPA’s first annual leadership conference designed especially for HPA Chapters — but open to anyone who is interested in developing leadership skills and learning more about the HPA's unique brand of fan activism! Our conference, held October 17 to 19, 2014, is designed to bring our greatest leaders together in one place and allow them to establish strong connections with each other, share ideas, learn from our talented staff, and emerge well-equipped to lead their community to a more just and magical future. Of course, this will be no ordinary leadership conference, as all programming and activities will be injected with the spirit of our most cherished stories. Whether most inspired by Hermione’s community organizing chops or Neville’s ability to stand up for what’s right regardless of the risk, attendees will be given the tools to become the heroes of their own narrative!

Registration for Granger Leadership Academy is $40 and includes all programming, keynote speakers, and a fanciful catered dinner on Saturday night.

All conference activity will occur at The Hotel at Auburn University. Rooms at the hotel will be available to attendees for $119 per night, and will hold up to four people. Attendees should plan to make their room reservations by September 26, 2014. We have secured a room block for Thursday, Friday, and Saturday nights.

Attendees should make their room reservations using the following link:
https://bookings.ihotelier.com/The-Hotel-at-Auburn-University/bookings.jsp?hotelID=6493&groupID=1248984

Granger Leadership Academy aims to provide attendees with dynamic training based on the Social Change Model of Leadership Development. Programming will be structured as follows:

Friday Morning: Individual (Self)
Friday Afternoon: Group (Chapter)
Saturday Morning: Community (Local and Greater HPA)
Saturday Afternoon: Citizenship (Creating Positive Change)

For more information, please see our website:
http://dft.ba/-gla

"Having conducted more than three years of research with Nerdfighters, I'm frustrated when this group is framed as simply a movie-going audience. Instead, Nerdfighters should be acknowledged as a self-standing online community, meaningful both as a source of friendship and support for young people, and as a site for civic learning and action. Nerdfighters simply call it "decreasing world suck."

Nerdfighters are a creative and unorthodox bunch, as likely to be playing a hand-made ukulele as they are to be shooting the next installment of their collective video-blog on YouTube.

Unlike what the media coverage may suggest, Nerdfighters aren't just "fans of John Green" (or his brother Hank, who for Nerdfighters holds the same celebrity status). The Green brothers are only one common ground uniting Nerdfighters.

Rather, Nerdfighteria is a place where young people meet like-minded others, and can proudly let their "inner nerd" shine. It is a place where they can share their most intimate worries and concerns. Just as Esther shared her struggles with cancer, other Nerdfighters share the problems they face, such as their parents' divorce, battling depression, or uncertainties around their sexual identities."

Check out this awesome article on Nerdfighteria, Esther Earl, and Esther Day from our friend Neta Kligler-Vilenchik!

Chapters! The deadline to apply for our summer Granger Grant is tomorrow.

Thanks to a very successful fundraising effort in September and October 2013, the HPA is now in a position to help chapters realize their most ambitious goals with an exclusive grant program for chapters! The Granger Grant for Excellence in Community Organizing is a biannual event awarding one top prize ($1,000) and three runner-up prizes ($500 each) to chapters that are able to best demonstrate the following three qualities: 1) A history of outstanding achievements in the HPA chapters program. 2) An innovative and groundbreaking vision for action in the upcoming year. 3) A concrete plan to turn that vision into reality.

Find out more and apply at the link below.

Here's what we'll be doing this Saturday! Our President, Andrew Slack will join Lori and Wayne Earl from This Star Won't Go Out in a livestream as part of our Esther Day campaign. We'll kick off at 2:30PM, since we know many of you will be buying your LeakyCon Open at the Close tickets at 2PM.

See you there!

After serving as the Harry Potter Alliance's Executive Director for six years, co-founder Andrew Slack is stepping out of the position. No, we didn't vote him off the island: Andrew will become the Harry Potter Alliance's President and the Director of the Imagine Better Network.

Andrew’s new focus will be on turning our work into a movement by sharing the HPA’s methodology with other organizations, schools, and fan activist groups so that we can expand our civic imagination and work for a world beyond the injustices in our status quo. 

Please join us in congratulating Andrew on his new roles.

Having co-founded the Harry Potter Alliance, served as a founding Board Member, and, for the past year and a half, worked as the Director of Campaigns and Operations, Paul DeGeorge is now stepping up to become the HPA’s Executive Director.

Paul succeeds Andrew Slack, founding Executive Director, who is transitioning to President of the HPA and Director of the Imagine Better Network. Paul brings to the role strong leadership and vision for the HPA as well as over a decade of practical experience.

Please join us in congratulating Paul!

Get to know Paul DeGeorge, our new Executive Director!

Paul’s been there, done that, and probably designed the t-shirt. We put together this timeline to show you just some of the things he’s done, both within the HPA and outside of it.

To the Glee fandom:

We've said it before: we're with you.

We were devastated to learn Cory Monteith passed away one year ago tonight. After all, we're fans, too. We understand all too well that this day is a difficult one for many.

We believe that the weapon we have is love. Cory once said that "love is how you stay alive even after you're gone." And from what we've seen, Cory's not going anywhere.

Our thoughts and hearts go out to Cory's family, friends, and fans.

LeakyCon is so soon that it's kinda blowing our minds. We'll have more information on all our plans and panels coming your way soon!

In the meantime, don't forget that our Apparating Library will be making an appearance. Start thinking about which book you want to contribute to the most magical book swap ever. We only request that you steer clear of horcruxes.

Economix's comic about net neutrality gives us the 101 on why the internet is in danger and why we should care.

You can help protect the internet by signing out petition and spreading the word: http://salsa3.salsalabs.com/o/50409/p/dia/action3/common/public/?action_KEY=13907

This image is not for Rita Skeeter's benefit.

She doesn't get it. Love doesn't have to be a tabloid headline. Love doesn't even have to be romantic. 

In Harry Potter, platonic love saves the wizarding world. Mothers put their lives on the line. Teachers protect their students at all costs. Friends live and die for friends.

Harry loves Hermione. Hermione loves Harry. Their friendship is powerful. Their friendship is important. Their friendship is not scandalous.

It doesn't have to be.

On Esther Day, we celebrate family, friendship, and love. Learn more and join us as we count down to August 3rd: http://estherday.org
story: The Harry Potter Alliance with Marlin Morrison.

message:
Hey, do you love YouTube?

Maybe you've heard about this thing called Net Neutrality. 

It's the idea that once you've paid for your internet service, you should have equal access to the entire internet: from your favorite independent YouTube creators and to streaming services like Netflix or Hulu. 

But internet service providers (ISPs) want that to end. They want to be able to charge the content creators to get onto your computer screens: a service that you’ve already paid for. 

This is a big week in the fight to preserve Net Neutrality. 

The FCC’s public comment period ends this Friday. 

Take a few minutes to watch our friend Hank Green’s video on net neutrality and sign this petition which sends comments directly to the FCC.

Tell the FCC that you love YouTube. Tell them about how independent video creators have enriched your life and remind them that it was made possible by Net Neutrality. 

Let them know now!

Rule #1 of the Apparating Library: DFTBA and have fun.

Rule #2 of the Apparating Library: Don’t bring books that tell you to cast spells you know nothing about on your enemies. Just don’t.

The Apparating Library will be at LeakyCon in less than two weeks! Choose your book carefully.

message: LeakyCon was where it all began for our Apparating Library, so we're extra excited to finally be going back after a year of stops around the country. If you're packing for LeakyCon soon, don't forget to bring a book!

"… and to you, if you have stuck with Harry until the very end."

Here’s to book seven. Here’s to the years of anticipation before it and the years of discussion in its wake. Here’s to the boy who lived and how he changed everything.

And here’s to you, if you know that “the very end” isn't happening anytime soon.

We are book eight.

--

Seven years ago, the world said it was the end of an era. News outlets prepared for what they thought - and perhaps hoped - would be their final coverage of the Harry Potter phenomenon. While small bookstores celebrated alongside readers, big box stores were gearing up for “one last midnight release.”

Seven years ago, we knew better. We were ready. We were decked out from head to toe, friends new and old by our side and wand at the ready. Maybe we were lining up, filling stores and sidewalks with our excited chatter, shutting down Harvard Yard with our music movement, pushing our favorite fansites’ servers to their limits. We were loud because we knew the rest of the night would be spent in silence. We knew we’d be reading well into daylight. And we did.

Despite that, parts of us were scared that - beyond all reason - they were right. Scared that it would inexplicably fizzle out, that this would be the last time, that we’d reunite briefly for the remaining movies and then move on. We knew this wouldn’t happen, but fear resists reason and we were scared.

Seven years later, we’re still going strong and it’s easy to laugh at those fleeting concerns. It’s easier still to forget that we made this happen. We made conscious decisions to keep the Harry Potter community alive, to talk about what we’d just read and wonder what would happen next. Even when the first wave of discussion died down, the fandom went on. We hadn’t stopped loving Harry Potter. We’d only just begun.

Seven years ago, the Harry Potter Alliance was still just starting out. We’s made some big strides and had some - okay, more than just some - big ideas. In the time since then, you’ve helped us make some incredible moments possible. There are already too many campaigns, discussions, and memories to nail down in one tidy list. This fandom’s commitment to Harry Potter and each other is what made those big ideas possible and makes them possible still.

Today, we’ll be celebrating the book that brought us all together - not for the first time and not for the last - seven years ago.

But first, we want to celebrate this community: the one that saw Harry through until the very end, the one that already has new things to count down to, the one that knows know what it knew then.

Thank you.

Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows was released seven years ago. The fandom spent a long time speculating about Book Eight, wanting nothing more than another installment.

Today, we know that there are at least three new Harry Potter movies ahead of us. We know that there will be a play about Harry's early days. There are even whispers of a new book or something equally momentous under J.K. Rowling's sleeve.

But none of those are the eighth book. The Harry Potter series was not succeeded by the news of a theme park attraction or Pottermore. It was succeeded by the same community that saw it through.

We are book eight. And there's a t-shirt for that: dftba.com/product/1ag/We-Are-Book-Eight-Shirt

message:
"The [Esther Earl Rockin’ Charity Ball] is on Esther Day, and they’re gonna dance in [Esther’s] honor. Thousands of people dancing - ‘cause Esther, she said - and I’m quoting her tweet - 'I just want to be able to reach into bodies and pull out the cancer without hurting anybody, and I want to be able to dance. And I want the gift of words.'

And she’s got it.

She can’t dance - she’s not here to dance - but every time we look around the room and we see people dancing, we see Esther. And every time somebody does something good and right and honorable, we’re doing the work that she can no longer do."

- Wayne Earl, Esther Earl's father, in the Here and Now piece on Esther.

We’ve spent our summer apparating from one con to another, so our physical merch table has been pretty busy. Thanks to wizard science and our friends at DFTBA Records, however, all our wizard wearables (including shirts for people and walls) are also available through the internet. We’ve even gotten the Ministry of Magic to let us lift all the charms on it and make it available beyond the Floo Network.

Now you can rep the internet with our Hogwarts Internet Club and Grangr t-shirts. There’s also our super-swanky Books Turn Muggles Into Wizards journal, which we promise is not a horcrux. And if you’re in need of some encouragement, you can hang the Hang in There, Baby Crookshanks poster on your wall for instant, furry moral support.

These are the latest in our merch line, which includes some of our old favorites like the Granger/Lovegood 2016 campaign tee and our classy HPA logo shirt. So classy.

We’d love to see you at our booths and tables across the country (LeakyCon Orlando, anyone?), but the internet’s got your back if you can’t make it.

Each purchase helps support our work at the Harry Potter Alliance. So thanks!

Feel free to buy all the things. 

http://dftba.com/artist/75/Harry-Potter-Alliance

We are deeply saddened by Robin Williams’ passing and join the world in mourning him.

When the people who help us fight off dementors fall victim to their effects, hope and happiness can seem almost unattainable. We are all so indebted to the entertainers of the world that it seems only logical that the universe should give at least a fraction of their brightness back to them. Instead, they too often face darkness so deep that remembering to turn on the light isn’t always an option.

Robin Williams’ work as a comedian, actor, and philanthropist reached millions. Whether it was as Genie, John Keating, Peter Pan, Theodore Roosevelt, or just as Robin, he brought the world a unique and invaluable happiness. It was he who said that “comedy is acting out optimism.” Though the world knew him for that optimism, behind the scenes he was battling his own dementors.

These moments of shock give us the chance to move forward with open minds and open hearts. For so many, seeking help is an insurmountable task. Having people listen and understand can be the strongest patronus there is.

As we navigate this difficult news, we can work to make the truth stronger by speaking more honestly and listening more openly. We can honor Robin Williams by driving out not just our own dementors, but each others’.

The weapon we have is love.

message:
John Oliver's segment on the situation in Ferguson.

“The phrase ‘bring it, you f***ing animals’ is barely acceptable during a zoo escape. It’s not even acceptable in the restaurant in Mary Poppins, where penguins are waiters. That kind of statement betrays an inability to see the citizens of Ferguson as individuals, and instead treats them as a threatening whole. And that is a top-down problem.”

Franchesca "Chescaleigh" Ramsey's video on Ferguson and Mike Brown is a must-watch.

"Mike Brown is essentially being put on trial for his own murder. […] And I’m pretty sure someone’s going to accuse me of ‘playing the race card’ because it happens every time I talk about race, oppression or privilege on the internet and in real life as if this is a fun game of Uno or something. Look, protests and signing petitions and marches and crying are not fun. This is not a fun experience. If you want to accuse me of ‘playing the race card,’ then let’s all agree that white privilege is the ultimate royal flush.”

If you use YouTube, you need to know this.

You’ve heard all these rumblings about Net Neutrality over the past several months. Let’s get real: this is about controlling online video. It is estimated that by 2017, video content will account for 80-90% of all global Internet traffic (1). 

This isn’t just about not being able to binge-watch a series on Netflix. It’s about the future of online video as we know it.

Whether your YouTube channel is home to daily vlogs, short films, or just that one video from when the cinnamon challenge seemed like a good idea, you’re a video creator. Your content and comments help shape this community. Let’s keep it that way.

Net Neutrality means that your YouTube videos reach people at the same speed as clips from last night’s episode of the Tonight Show. It means a level playing field for video creators looking to reach an audience. But new Net Neutrality rules could mess that up. 

Here’s the deal: Telecommunications companies already charge us to access the Internet through our homes and our phones. New FCC rules could allow them to also charge content providers (like YouTube, Netflix, and even PBS) for access to our eyeballs. It could create a fast lane for Jimmy Fallon’s clips, and slow lane for your YouTube videos. 

It is really important that the FCC understands that online video creators care about Net Neutrality. Even if you’ve only ever uploaded ONE VIDEO, you are a creator and you have a voice. 

If you can, please add your channel to our petition. We’ll deliver this to the FCC in September and demonstrate that the online video community cares about this issue. 

Sign the petition here, then spread the word: http://www.videocreatorsfornetneutrality.org/

SOURCES:
1. http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/solutions/collateral/service-provider/ip-ngn-ip-next-generation-network/white_paper_c11-481360.html

From Reuters: "As of Wednesday, dozens of online personalities had joined the effort on http://www.videocreatorsfornetneutrality.org/. Those creators represent more than 10,000 videos that have been viewed 5.2 billion times, according to the website."

Learn more and sign the petition: http://www.videocreatorsfornetneutrality.org/

The YouTube community needs net neutrality.

If big companies had their way, content would stop being equally accessible. For YouTubers, uploading videos would be next to impossible to begin with and viewers would have to wait hours just to watch one video. Meanwhile, network television clips and dodgy advertisements would get priority access to your eyeballs.

Without net neutrality, channels like the Vlogbrothers may never have existed. That’s a pretty scary thought. Look at it this way: how would your life be different if you had never seen the Vlogbrothers’ videos? How has Nerdfighteria impacted you?

Comment with your story, then sign the petition to support net neutrality.

http://www.videocreatorsfornetneutrality.org/

message:
Happy World Literacy Day!

At the Harry Potter Alliance, we know stories can change the world. We know we can become the heroes we read about. We know books are magic.

We know these things because we've seen them at work. Together, the Harry Potter community has raised over 150,000 books for underserved and underpriviliged communities around the world and swapped books across oceans.

There's no better way to honor that something very magical J.K. Rowling spoke about than to see it through. There's no better way to celebrate literacy than to spread it.

"I always knew from that moment, from the time I found myself at home in that little segregated library in the South, all the way up until I walked up the steps of the New York City library, I always felt, in any town, if I can get to a library, I'll be okay. It really helped me as a child, and that never left me. So I have a special place for every library, in my heart of hearts." - Maya Angelou. Happy World Literacy Day!

We don't make the rules. (It's probably not actually mandatory, but you should still get the shirt. Just in case. This design is also available as a t-shirt for your wall and a journal.)

http://www.dftba.com/artist/75/Harry-Potter-Alliance

Happy World Literacy Day!

YouTubers: This is your chance to make a statement about the internet in a big way. Upload and submit a video about net neutrality and it’ll play on a billboard outside FCC headquarters on September 16th.

We’re not kidding. This is real. Submit your video at http://bit.ly/VC4NN.

Notice your favorite sites running a bit slow today? Here's what you'll see if you visit ours'. It's all part of the #InternetSlowdown to illustrate what the internet would be like under the proposed "slow lanes." 

If you want to keep fighting for a free and open internet, join http://videocreatorsfornetneutrality.org to show the FCC how important the internet is to our community. #vc4nn

story: The Harry Potter Alliance shared their photo.

message:
The YouTube community needs net neutrality.

The world is better off with the Potter Puppet Pals in them. Whether you've only seen Mysterious Ticking Noise or consider yourself a seasoned puppet historian, it's clear that these puppets could probably take over the world. Instead, they make people laugh. We're happy they're here, and we're happy we can get our PPP fix whenever we want to just by going to their channel. We want it to stay that way.

If big cable companies had their way, content would stop being equally accessible. For YouTubers, uploading videos would be next to impossible to begin with and we’d have to wait hours just to watch one video. Meanwhile, network television clips and dodgy advertisements would get priority access to your eyeballs.

We need to let the FCC know where we stand.

Join thousands of channels in signing the petition:
http://videocreatorsfornetneutrality.org

Submit a video to play on a billboard outside FCC headquarters: http://bit.ly/VC4NN

This brother and sister’s video about why #NetNeutrality matters to them as videobloggers is one of the videos that will be playing on a billboard outside the FCC’s offices today. 

Want to add your voice to the cause? You have one hour remaining to upload a video to be played on the billboard (http://bit.ly/VC4NN) or sign this petition to the FCC: http://videocreatorsfornetneutrality.org

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=y2ssO3YV6kU&list=UUqetMW-cw1ez2xO_iiqyavg
Less than a half hour remains before we submit your signatures to the FCC. Sign the petition now! http://videocreatorsfornetneutrality.org

This is John Oliver's epic #NetNeutrality video playing on a billboard outside the FCC offices right now. Want to see your face there? Submit a video before tomorrow afternoon and our friends at Fight For The Future and Namecheap will make sure everyone at the FCC sees it right outside their office windows. Submit your video here: http://bit.ly/VC4NN

At the Harry Potter Alliance, we turn fans into heroes. We believe that we can change the world using the resources available to us and the enthusiasm we have for stories, friendships, and social good. We see this in action every day.

What we do is only possible because of the people we do it with.

Today we’ve launched Equality FTW, our annual fundraiser. Please check it out at http://EqualityFTW.org.

We have some amazing perks this year from John Green, Hank Green, Maureen Johnson, Evanna Lynch, Team StarKid, and even J.K. Rowling.

When you support the Harry Potter Alliance, you’re supporting fan activism. You’re supporting 275 of our chapters. You’re helping to make Hogwarts real with the Granger Leadership Academy. You’re making a difference for economic, educational and LGBTQ equality.

You can learn more and donate to Equality FTW here. Spread the word. Join in.

The Weapon We Have is Love.

Banned Books Week celebrates some of literature’s most challenged titles. Unlike the books in the restricted section at Hogwarts, banned books aren’t challenged because they teach kids how to take on other people’s appearances or split their souls in pursuit of immortality. Instead, banned books present stories that need to be told but rarely are.

We’re celebrating Banned Books Week by talking about some of our favorite banned books. We’ve also started the Azkabanned Books Club as a way to stand against censorship all year round. The t-shirt is available as a perk for our Equality FTW fundraiser, but will only be sold through this week. Grab yours: http://equalityftw.org

message:
A California school district has banned The Fault In Our Stars from middle school libraries. This is exactly the kind of news we don't want to hear in the middle of #BannedBooksWeek... or ever.

Books like TFiOS help its readers navigate issues that would otherwise be swept under the rug. This decision is a harsh reminder that - often - the readers affected by book bannings are the ones who need those stories the most.

In celebration of Banned Books Week, we've designed Azkabanned Books Club t-shirts as a way to stand against censorship all year round. The t-shirt is available as a perk for our Equality FTW fundraiser, but will only be sold through this week. http://equalityftw.org/

Forgot to get Ollivander a birthday present? We've got you covered.

Earlier this year we started publishing our own quarterly magazine, the W.A.N.D. (Wizard Activist News Dispatch). This is the first time we’ve offered subscriptions to the magazine. A $40 donation to our Equality FTW fundraiser gets you four issues, delivered directly to your door (by owls).

Rumor has it that Ollivander's really into wand puns *and* wizard activism, so your subscription would probably make his day.

Today is our ninth birthday. We were founded in 2005 with one simple goal: to turn fans into heroes. For nine years, your support has made that dream a reality. 

We like to use our birthday as a chance to reflect on the past years and today we ask you to join us in doing so by sharing this post with how being a part of the HPA has helped validate your experience as a fan. 

We’ll share some of our favorites throughout the day and some of them might even be shared on air during our birthday party tonight at 8 pm ET.

Thank you for a magical nine years.

Plz RSVP to our birthday party tonight. We'll have wizard rock musicians, special guests, and even the ref from our quidditch match against LeakyCon. Plus loads more. This party is BYOP.


*Bring Your Own Pizza

We’re celebrating Indigenous People’s Day in affirmation of what should be self-evident: much of what we know and enjoy has been made possible by atrocities committed against others. In order to truly move forward, we must acknowledge these crimes and make whatever reparations are possible.

Christopher Columbus’ “discovery” of America was followed by the genocide and enslavement of tens of millions of native people. His actions led to the transatlantic slave trade and centuries of violence and discrimination towards indigenous people. Yet we celebrate him as an American hero.  

We applaud Seattle and Minneapolis in their recent shift away from Columbus Day, as well as Berkeley for first making the change in the early nineties. It is our hope that these are the first of many. Please join us in celebrating Indigenous People’s Day and moving towards a more honest, inclusive future.

Congratulations, Alaska and Arizona!

Bans on marriage equality have been struck down in both these states today.

We want to see more victories like this across the board. We want to see progress towards marriage equality, gender equality, racial equality, and so much more. We want to see all human rights become inalienable.

This is what we fight for.

If you’d like to help us keep fighting, please consider donating to and spreading the word about our annual fundraiser, Equality FTW: http://equalityftw.org

Vondell Swain’s incredible Harry Potter art has been making waves in the fandom for months, creating important discussions about how we read fiction and why diverse representation is vital. We’ve long been fans of Vondell’s art, which is why so excited to announce that his James, Lily, and Harry Potter pieces are available as buttons exclusively through Equality FTW!

Vondell explains, “Personally I’m mentally acting against the white-as-default-unless-otherwise-specified that’s pervasive in imagining media especially in predominantly white fandom culture. In absence of a specified race I chose to imagine the one that makes the story most compelling to me.”

The Harry Potter Alliance turns fans into heroes, fighting for equality with the stories we love at the core of each campaign. Fan activism is growing and accomplishing new things each day, so it’s more important than ever that we fight for equality not just inspired by fiction, but within it.

This fundraiser helps us keep fighting for equality. It ends this Saturday.

You can donate and learn more about what we do at http://equalityftw.org

Our fundraiser ends tonight at 3 am EDT (midnight on the west coast) and we're going out with a bang. Join us tonight on Google Hangout, where we'll be joined by some special guests to celebrate the successful end of Equality FTW and drive home as many last minute donations as we can all together.

story: The Harry Potter Alliance added an event.

message:
Today is the last day of our fundraiser. So far 3,423 of you have donated to raise $130,461. We blew past our goal and can’t thank you enough, but with just 17 hours left, we want to see how far we can go. How far can fan activists go? http://equalityftw.org

If you haven’t donated yet, please do. This is your last chance! We even brought back two limited edition perks in case you missed getting them earlier in the campaign. You now have a few more hours to snag a pumpkin spice t-shirt or become a proud member of the Azkabanned Books Club.

If you have already donated, please help us spread the word in these final hours. Signal boost this post, write your own, reach out one-on-one to individuals in your life and let them know what it means to you to be a fan activist and why they should donate if they can.

To close out the fundraiser tonight, we’ll all be celebrating together with the Equality FTW Closing Ceremonies Telethon. Come join us and some special guests from 9 pm ET until the campaign officially ends at 3 am (that’s 6 pm - midnight PT): https://www.facebook.com/events/573740519422028/?ref=22 

It’s been an amazing month seeing fans come together in the name of decreasing world suck. With just seventeen hours left, let’s show the world what fans can do.

Donate here and spread the word: http://equalityftw.org

message:
Congratulations to International Academy Order of the Phoenix of Bloomfield Hills, Michigan! They’ve officially won this year’s Equality FTW Chapters Cup by generating $2,392 in donations to the fundraiser. Their work is impressive and inspiring.
 
Thanks to our participating chapters, $8,236 of donations to this year's Equality FTW campaign came from our amazing chapters program. You can find out more about chapters near you or how to start one yourself at http://thehpalliance.org/chapters/
#GoVote's website is your one-stop for getting informed before tomorrow's elections. Check it out and pass it on:

Here are some resources for tomorrow's elections:

http://www.theballot.org/ tells you what will be on your ballot.
https://2014.votinginfoproject.org/ tells you your polling place.
http://www.headcount.org/election-info/ provides a wealth of information on where to vote, what to bring, and so much more you need to know.
http://www.brennancenter.org/student-voting is NYU's thorough guide for student voters across the nation.

Know anything else that might help? Comment to add on or just to signal boost this list. Your voice is powerful. Don't let it go unheard when it matters most.

A reminder from Harry Potter that voting prevents the election of officials like Umbridge. Go vote tomorrow and signal boost this to remind all your friends. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LEakYkB0Xp4&index=6&list=PLP3imAa1WlVm6R8JNy8n61wXw-K-oM-o6

Make time to vote tomorrow.

Find out when polling places open and close near you: http://www.nonprofitvote.org/states/

In the meantime, tweet your questions and comments in the #District13 tag and RSVP here: https://plus.google.com/events/c9i288duj2b4sfkj8vcprpd8ffg

The Odds In Our Favor campaign starts today.

Mockingjay Part 1, the third film in the Hunger Games series, premieres this week. With all eyes on this game-changing story, it’s the perfect time to take back the narrative.

The Hunger Games explores themes of economic inequality and government corruption that parallel issues prevalent in our world. It would do the trilogy a great disservice to disregard that commentary, to gossip about relationships and appearances, to capitalize off the shock value. Unfortunately, that’s exactly what’s happening.

So we’re taking this into our own hands.

We want to hear your stories - the daily realities, the struggles, and the triumphs big and small. The ways race, gender, sexual orientation, bodily status, familial origin, and more intersect and inform how you’re treated. Economic inequality manifests itself in our daily lives and yet even alluding to it is frowned upon. Now is the time to shine a light on it.

Let’s do just that. Share your stories. Own your experiences. See how the catharsis of telling your truth can educate, empower, and effect change. If the gamemakers are going to perpetuate the culture of silence, it’s up to us to raise our voice.

Tell your story here or by tweeting, instragramming, making a video - whatever you do, tag it #MyHungerGames to include it in the discussion. We’ll be highlighting our favorites here and on our We Are The Districts blog (http://wearethedistricts.tumblr.com).

Let’s shift the odds into our favor.
#MyHungerGames is taking off on twitter. What's your Hunger Games story?

These #MyHungerGames stories show how economic inequality turns basic food security into a privilege.

What's your story? Share it in the #MyHungerGames tag. Take back the narrative.

Suzanne Collins came up with the idea for The Hunger Games while flipping between a news broadcast and a reality show. Today, there’s not much difference between news broadcasts and the Hunger Games films.

Tons of people are posting their #MyHungerGames stories. The movement even caught the attention of The Daily Dot. Share your story and join the conversation using #MyHungerGames. http://www.dailydot.com/entertainment/harry-potter-alliance-my-hunger-games/?tw=dd
What's your #MyHungerGames story?
Tell your Hunger Games story about your experiences with economic inequality using the hashtag #MyHungerGames.

Keep sharing your #MyHungerGames stories! Join the movement. Take back the narrative.

If you're going to see Mockingjay Pt. 1 tonight or this weekend, be sure to take a picture of you, your friends, or even the entire movie theater doing the three-finger salute.

Learn more about our campaign at http://oddsinourfavor.org

#TBT to the Catching Fire premiere!

Since we first ran our Odds In Our Favor campaign this time last year, the three-finger salute has only become more powerful. It’s become a symbol of change and solidarity around the world. When you go see #Mockingjay - we know lots of you will be heading out to the premiere tonight - remember to take a picture of you, your friends in line, or even the whole theater doing the three-finger salute. We’ll be sharing them on all our platforms.

Meanwhile, the #MyHungerGames tags continue to showcase brave stories from those facing economic inequality. Check those out and join the movement.

Take back the narrative.

Learn more about our Odds In Our Favor at http://oddsinourfavor.org

He writes: "This is for my homie Andrew Slack [President of the Harry Potter Alliance], doing an amazing job organizing fans of The Hunger Games into real life activists."

Brandan turns abandoned places in post-Katrina New Orleans and turns them into places for inspiring artistic expression. This piece can be found at Exhibit Be, an abandoned apartment complex Brandan has turned into a street art exhibit. You can learn more here: http://brandanodums.com/be/

We're awed and honored by this moving take on the three-finger salute. Check out Brandan's incredible work, then join the #MyHungerGames movement by reading others' stories (https://storify.com/TheHPAlliance/odds-in-our-favor) and sharing your own.

"This week, fans of the popular Hunger Games series relaunched a campaign called “Odds in Our Favor” to draw attention to economic and social inequality. The campaign asks fans to “fill the gap” between the social commentary of The Hunger Games and the world fans inhabit by sharing their stories of economic inequality with the hashtag #MyHungerGames.

The result has been an outpouring of personal stories about hunger, poverty, and health care inequity."

Read more Hunger Games stories, then share yours: https://storify.com/TheHPAlliance/odds-in-our-favor

We are devastated by the grand jury's decision to deny Mike Brown and his loved ones justice. We stand with the people of Ferguson and hope for their safety.

In the months since Mike Brown was murdered, we’ve seen protesters - from those on-site to those online - tirelessly demanding justice and lasting change. We’ve seen discussions that have been going on for decades gain urgency and long overdue attention. Though there is absolutely nothing that could dull the pain surrounding this tragedy and every tragedy like it, we commend all those working and calling for help. We are committed to standing with and among them.

Tonight, we send our love to Mike Brown, his loved ones, and all those who live this reality every day.

“#MyHungerGames was started by a nonprofit media literacy and fan activism organization called The Harry Potter Alliance as part of its larger “Odds In Our Favor” campaign, which aims to “take back” the film’s narrative from glossy studio marketing efforts.

For those unaware, the series is set in a dystopic future North American region called Panem, where one very rich and powerful class (The Capitol) rules over the majority of the population — a population that has been divided into 13 increasingly oppressed, disenfranchised and impoverished districts.

[…]

Since the hashtag was launched last week, nearly 5,000 people have used it to share their own stories of economic inequality on Twitter. Hundreds more have turned to Tumblr with the hashtag to explain just how much the issue has affected their own lives.”

Share your #MyHungerGames stories on your social media platform of choice.

More can be found here: https://storify.com/TheHPAlliance/odds-in-our-favor

Here are a couple of the many ways you can help and support #Ferguson:

The library is short on resources and staff. We can help them out by donating money through the PayPal button on their website (http://ferguson.lib.mo.us/) or sending book donations to

Ferguson Public Library

Author Sara Benincasa said it best on twitter: the library is ”a place of peace, learning, inquiry, home. An oasis.”

Today - as with everyday - we are thankful. We are thankful for your constant support, your contributions to important discussions, your commitment to both unironic enthusiasm and social change. We are thankful that our ever-growing membership is so eager to change the world in positive, compassionate ways. We are thankful that we can continue to work alongside you.

And we hope you’re thankful, too - that you are enjoying the privilege and necessity of gratitude with those you love, whether it be around a dinner table or through the internet.

But we cannot celebrate today without acknowledging all of its implications. We cannot pretend that this holiday or the nation that celebrates it was built ethically or even harmlessly. We cannot forget the atrocities perpetrated against Native Americans at its origin, and we cannot ignore the ongoing epidemic of often lethal violence against black people. Our history and present are fraught with injustice; if we hope to change the future, we must remember this.

While we welcome the opportunity to celebrate and engage in gratitude, it cannot overshadow the need for consciousness and change. Today we are thankful, but we’re also thoughtful, mournful and - ultimately - hopeful.

message: Black Friday has come and gone, but our actions against economic inequality are ongoing. Between now and December 4th, we’re encouraging action on behalf of low wage workers at McDonald's. These workers struggle with the same issues that workers in the districts face: low pay, bad hours and working conditions, hunger, lack of affordable healthcare, and more. Here's how you can help: Visit your local McDonald's. Take a selfie doing the three finger salute and upload it with the #MyHungerGames hashtag. Next, ask to speak to the manager. Give the manager one of these fact sheets (http://thehpalliance.org/oiof-mcdonalds.pdf) and encourage them to read it and consider how their company treats and compensates its workers. After you’ve delivered these fact sheets, share your experiences with us through #MyHungerGames.

As we process the devastating news that a New York City grand jury has decided Eric Garner’s murder unworthy of a fair trial, our hearts are heavy. We send all those mourning him love and light.

Days like today are never easy and never welcome, but they are common. They were common centuries ago, common in the civil rights movement we pretend is a distant past, and common still. The need for change is urgent and overwhelming. All of us must play our part in fighting against the decriminalization of racially-motivated murder. All of us must do what we can.

We thank and commend all those joining the movement to demand change. Whether it be by onsite protest or online discussion, your voices matter. You are making a difference.

Along with Mike Brown, Tamir Rice, and the long list of stories like 
theirs, Eric Garner is on our minds as we go forward from this moment.

As part of our Odds In Our Favor campaign, we partnered with Fight for 15 to organize Thursday's nationwide #StrikeFastFood protests. Protesters adopted the Hunger Games' three-finger salute as a display of strength and solidarity. Many groups also took moments to honor Michael Brown and other victims of racially-motivated police brutality.

Economic inequality is not an isolated issue. It intersects and overlaps with race, gender, sexuality, health - the list goes on. As we fight to shift the odds in our favor, it's vital that we keep that in mind.

"We all know how strong and sometimes terrifying fandoms can be. You could go on twitter today and post a picture of a kid from Target bagging your purchase and you would get so many followers and an entire fandom will come out of it in a matter of hours. I mean, this just shows the power of fandom - on social media especially - today. Now, think - if only we could harness this energy that’s in fandoms and use it for a good cause.

Lucky for the world, we don’t have to imagine such a thing.In 2005, a group of eager fans of a particular boy wizard saw the global inequalities of the world and became witches and wizards themselves to make a difference through their fandom. The Harry Potter Alliance came out of this ideal.

They’ve produced many successful campaigns covering topics of illiteracy, homophobia, child slavery, the climate crisis, and many more. In 2014 alone, the Harry Potter Alliance’s annual fundraiser Equality FTW raised over $150,000 to help fund another year of fan activism. This includes working for economic, educational, and LGBTQ equality. The Equality FTW fundraiser hits very close to home for me as someone part of the LGBTQ community. And honestly, who doesn’t love an excuse to celebrate Harry Potter in the process?”

While you're supporting the HPA during Project for Awesome, be sure to give our friends NaNoWriMo some love, too!

"Over the years the HPA has run a lot of great campaigns for great causes, ranging from things like literacy to social and economic equality to fair trade to net neutrality. My favorite of these is the Accio Books campaign, which takes books donations for a community in need. This year alone, over 53,000 books were donated. The HPA is doing amazing work and it makes me feel great to know that fans can come together for no other reason than to support other people who need it."
