Our love and thoughts are with those affected by the school shooting in Pakistan - the victims, their loved ones, and everybody in mourning around the world.

This also extends to all those who are facing the heightened fears and dangers of racism at the hands of people who take advantage of tragedies like these to wrongly justify their hatred. It is unjust that anybody should feel less safe today because of the garments they choose, the religion they practice, or the origin of their story. We lament that this is the reality so many are facing in the wake of this terrible news.

If any of this affects you, please know that you are loved. And if you are able, please do what you can to spread and promote love in the communities you call home. There is nothing more powerful in times like these.

Please take a moment to read about some major changes to the HPA’s leadership from our co-founder and former Executive Director, Paul DeGeorge. We have been honored to work with Paul on a day-to-day basis for the past two years and look forward to seeing the weird and amazing things he creates next. Good luck on your immortal adventures with Stephen Colbert and Santa Claus, Paul. We’ll meet again some sunny day.

=====

Today I’m stepping down as Executive Director of the Harry Potter Alliance.

As I’ve been preparing for this, a lot of friends and family have expressed either curiosity or dismay at my decision. Why would I leave this amazing job? It’s a great question to ask and one I’ve wrestled with for quite some time. The truth is, I don’t have a spectacularly great answer for it, at least not in the conventional sense. I’m not leaving this job for another. Instead, I’m leaving because I’m curious to see what happens. It’s a challenge to myself to keep pushing forward, to keep learning, to keep experimenting and to keep creating. It’s a personal decision to embrace that next adventure. I will, however, continue to stay involved with the HPA as a member of the Board of Directors.

As a co-founder of the Harry Potter Alliance, it’s difficult to express the pride I feel for this organization. Over the past 10 years, I’ve played an intimate role in shaping this organization and that feels like such a privilege. Like any non-profit, the HPA started with an idea. But it’s been my experience that ideas only become reality when they’re nurtured and championed by talented, ambitious and dedicated people. In that respect, I am so grateful to everyone who has helped this organization over the years: our board members, our staff members, our volunteers, our chapter organizers, our members, our partners and everyone else who at one time or another has counted themselves as an ally to the HPA. Thank you all.

I know this is all starting to sound a bit bittersweet, but let me assure you it’s not. It’s just plain sweet. The Harry Potter Alliance is currently operating at the top of its game and I’ve never been more confident in its continued success. Earlier this year we completed a year-long strategic planning process and we’ve assembled an amazing team that is incredibly committed to our mission and ready to bring this plan forward. It’s a plan that will allow the HPA to continue redefining fandom and will turn “fan activism” into a household phrase.

I’m excited to announce that a key member of this team is our new Executive Director, Matthew Maggiacomo. You may know Matt as the human host body for the wizard rock band the Whomping Willows, but he’s also served as a longtime board member for the HPA. A year and a half ago, he left our board and joined our staff as our Chapters Director. In that time, we’ve seen unprecedented growth in our chapters program, particularly at a global level. We now have nearly 300 active HPA chapters (up from 120) in 43 states and 25 countries: each doing amazing work in their local communities. We’ve also created the Granger Leadership Academy, a weekend long training conference for chapter organizers and fan activists. All of this has happened under Matt’s leadership and I can’t wait to see what he does at the helm of the entire organization.

It has been such an honor to serve as the Executive Director of the Harry Potter Alliance. We’re on the cusp of major victories in Net Neutrality and in our Not In Harry’s Name campaign, and our recent work around the Hunger Games has transformed the cultural dialogue around economic inequality. I’m so proud of the work that our community has done in the name of equality and social justice. Thank you to everyone who has been a part of that work over the past nine and a half years.

Hedwig Lives,
Paul DeGeorge

message:
After over four years of dedication, our Not In Harry's Name campaign is officially a SUCCESS. Warner Bros. brand chocolate frogs will be Fair Trade certified by the end of this year!

Our Not in Harry's Name campaign first officially began in 2010, seeking to stop the unethical sourcing of Harry Potter chocolate. We wanted to make sure that child slavery would no longer be carried out in Harry's name. You joined us by signing petitions, spreading the word, and demanding Fair Trade products. Now, after years of collaboration with J.K. Rowling, Walk Free, and Warner Bros., we are thrilled to announce that we have won.

Our Not in Harry's Name victory is over four years in the making. Here's the story of how we got here.

Thanks to your videos, votes, and signal-boosting, we will be receiving a $25,000 grant. Other organizations receiving grants include our friends at This Star Won't Go Out and NaNoWriMo. The Project for Awesome makes a huge difference to small nonprofits like ours every year and we're beyond thankful.

As we observe Martin Luther King Jr. Day, we must take time to reflect and commit ourselves to progressive, compassionate change.

This holiday is, yes, one to celebrate - a day to consider the triumphs of the Civil Rights movements, the revolutionary contributions of black activists and artists, the story of everything that has led to today. But that cannot be all that it is. We cannot welcome the false sense of achievement we’ve been taught to slip into on the third Monday of every January. To do so would be to discredit the daily demonstrations demanding basic rights, deny the dangerous failings of the system, and diminish the mourning that weighs on communities that have come to know the realities of racism all too well.

We must regard today with solace and solemnity rather than with victory. And we must keep moving forward.

We must listen to firsthand accounts of oppression and marginalization. We must allow these stories to inform our worldview and advocacy. We must advocate vocally, but never speak for or over the group of the hour. We must speak and act with compassion, conscious of the power and privilege we carry. We must strive to educate ourselves. We must demand equality consistently and completely. 

We must do these things in King’s memory, yes, but also in Mike Brown’s, in Tamir Rice’s, in Sheneque Proctor’s - the list, to our great sorrow, goes on. And we must do these things with the urgent hope that together we can shift the tides and create a tomorrow where this is no longer our normal.

In his book recounting the Montgomery bus boycott, King wrote: "Human progress is neither automatic nor inevitable. Even a superficial look at history reveals that no social advance rolls in on the wheels inevitability. Every step towards the goal of justice requires sacrifice, suffering, and struggle; the tireless exertions and passionate concern of dedicated individuals. [...] This is no time for apathy or complacency. This is a time for vigorous and positive action."

Ferguson Action has organized #ReclaimMLK to take back a legacy that has been “clouded by efforts to soften, sanitize, and commercialize it.” Their vision is that “from here on, MLK weekend will be known as a time of national resistance to injustice.” You can learn more about these efforts and find other resources here: http://fergusonaction.com/movement/. Other celebrations include MTV’s decision to air all programming in black and white and the Selma cast and crew’s commemorative march from Selma to Montgomery.

Please join us in observing this holiday with remembrance, reflection, and action.
Our fair trade chocolate frog victory was mentioned on the premiere of Larry Wilmore's The Nightly Show last night. WE'RE KINDA FREAKING OUT.

One more thing: we’re super excited to have been mentioned on the show, but we do want to acknowledge the very important context here. We were referenced in a list of campaigns that have seen success while protests in the wake of police brutality and systemic violence against black lives have yet to see change or justice.

In the landscape of activism today, it is vital to recognize that many victories are owed in part to a certain privilege. The #BlackLivesMatter protests have not received the coverage or attention they need and deserve, and this radio silence is too easily accepted by the general public. Every success must come with the realization that, in these matters, no silence is accidental and all silence is harmful.

Even as we celebrate the Not in Harry’s Name victory referenced in the Nightly Show, we continue to stand with protesters from Ferguson to New York and around the world. Protest is powerful, and continued protest is resilient. Larry Wilmore’s segment is a reminder that protest works. We encourage you to join the movement, refuse to accept its erasure, and be part of its inevitable and necessary success.

Today's a big day for net neutrality, and we need you to help save the internet.

Our friends at Fight for the Future and Free Press have set up an amazing call tool on their excellent website, Battle for the Net. Simply enter your phone number (and keep your phone handy). The site will automatically connect you with your representative’s office and provide you with a short script. It’s super easy and it’ll make a big difference!

message:
Our hearts and thoughts go out to all affected by the Chapel Hill shooting, including the victims, their loved ones, and anybody who is left feeling less safe in the wake of this hate crime.

Tragedies like these come as harrowing reminders of the prevalence of prejudice and the importance of positive representation. Though Islamophobia is - unfortunately - nothing new, we have all seen hateful and harmful media with greater frequency and prominence in recent months. We have heard the reports of increased violence against Muslims. It is important, then, that we are mindful of the context surrounding this hate crime and that our mourning does not stop at solace, but instead becomes another reason to shift the tides and move forward.

#MuslimLivesMatter

Wondering what J.K. Rowling thinks of Hermione Granger as a Woman of Color? Her twitter favorites speak for themselves.

Since early February, Rowling has been favoriting pro-diversity thinkpieces and fanart alike, including Harry Potter Alliance Press Coordinator Alanna Bennett’s incredible Buzzfeed article (give it a read: http://www.buzzfeed.com/alannabennett/what-a-racebent-hermione-granger-really-represen-d2yp#.pwwOM8zxy)

Yeah. We’re flipping out, too. Even beyond this being a nod to one of our awesome volunteers, it’s a big sign that J.K. Rowling supports the growing movement of fans imagining their favorite characters complexly and diversely. Here’s hoping this is a precursor to J.K. Rowling becoming a more vocal supporter of diversity in popular fiction. We love fanart, but representation should be everywhere.

"In a time when many young people are growing increasingly cynical toward traditional mechanisms of political change, examples like the HPA’s Not in Harry’s Name campaign suggest that fan activism might be one key ingredient in the recipe for successful activism."

So. Net Neutrality is a thing now. An official, actual, real thing.

This is a huge win that’s going to protect the internet in very important ways. Our organization and the communities it calls home are all based out of the internet; today’s victory means it can stay that way for everybody.

We’ve been lucky enough to work with several awesome organizations to help make this happen. Part of that involved the Video Creators for Net Neutrality petition, which brought together hundreds of thousands of people to defend the content they create and consume. Big thanks go out to everybody who signed and spread the word.

We’re super stoked about the good news and hope you are, too. You can join the celebrations by talking about it (check out #NetNeutrality on the twitter in particular), continuing to watch your favorite YouTube channels, working your way through your Netflix to-watch list, blogging about things you love, speaking your mind, and making things. All of this and so much more is going to be possible for a long time thanks to Net Neutrality.

Become a Friend of the Apparating Library and help us get books to communities in need: http://apparatinglibrary.org

With your help, this campaign will fund Accio Books - our annual international book drive - and help us take it to new levels. Since our first Accio Books campaign in 2009, we’ve raised over 200,000 books for schools and communities in need and 
built libraries in Brooklyn and Rwanda. We've also created the Apparating Library, a progressive, community-generated library built by HPA members across the world over the course of several major fandom events, and organized the first Apparating Library book giveaway event in Detroit in 2014. There, thousands of books were distributed to families in need at the Brightmoor Community Center.

We're getting ready to do it all again this year, with TWO Apparating Library giveaways on two different continents and our most ambitious goal yet. But we need your help to do it.

The Harry Potter Alliance is unique in that 90% of our funding comes from our members, many of whom are part of literature-based fandoms. We don’t rely on the Malfoys of the world for big donations. We are built from the support of everyday fans like you.

To say thank you for your donations, we have a bunch of awesome perks available. This includes generous donations from our partners - books signed by Neil Gaiman, a compilation of songs about books by artists like Hank Green and Lauren Fairweather, GeekyCon exclusives that will help you skip the lines or get behind-the-scenes access at the event of the year, and more. We also have lots of in-house perks, from rad t-shirts to registration for the unparalleled Granger Leadership Academy conference. Each donation includes a Friends of the Apparating Library Membership, which will get you into our exciting new book club.

Are you in? Donate and spread the word!
Donate now to the Friends of the Apparating Library fundraiser and help put books in the hands of people who need them: apparatinglibrary.org

The HPA and Glee go way back. Many of our staffers remember the days of slushies and blazers a little too well. Especially in its first few years, we drew a lot of inspiration from Glee. Tonight, we want to take a moment to reflect on how thankful we are for that.

It was, as all of tumblr will readily tell you, a deeply imperfect show; its misses probably outnumbered its hits, and even its hits were always a little off-target. Still, Glee made great strides towards the kind of representation we need in our media. Things were very different when the pilot premiered. Glee didn’t cause the victories and steady progress in the six years between then and now, but it did help things along in its own way. The stories it told were ones the world needed - ones it still needs. As those stories finally start making their way into other shows, we can’t help but remember how it felt to see them play out in that choir room.

And, of course, Glee was - is - very important to the communities we call home. We’ve partnered with several of the show’s actors and are so grateful for their help. We see the breadth and depth of Glee’s influence every summer when we spend a weekend with people the show has helped bring together. Even those of us who didn’t see the show through sing along a little louder to a few songs - you know exactly which ones -  every single time out of an unshakeable bias.

Tonight, we’re thinking of Glee and its cast; we’re thinking of the people we lost along the way; more than anything, though, we’re thinking of you. Whether you jumped ship a few seasons in or rode it out until the end, whether you’ll be packing pink sunglasses and Dalton Academy ties in your summer con bags or pretending you never owned either, whether you saw yourself in this television show or you saw yourself in its fans, we’re glad you were here.

Keep loving imperfect things. Keep asking more of them. Keep making art about them. Keep being unapologetic in your love and enthusiasm for them no matter how much ratings drop. Keep making friends and memories that outlast them.

Don’t stop believing.

message: We've been given an anonymous tip that Rita Skeeter is planning on publishing a tell-all exposé of the HPA. As is to be expected from Skeeter, the book is completely slanderous and defamatory. Our legal team is hard at work trying to put a stop to this book's publication, but in the mean time, we're releasing our own statements in order to preempt the libel. If you have any helpful information about this horrendous upcoming publication, we'll be following posts under #HPAexposed.

Here's the foreword to Rita Skeeter's tell-all book about the HPA, which was sent to us by our brave insider at the publishing plant. Let's just clear one thing up right off the bat: We are NOT in the Illuminati. We just really think Nicolas Cage would've been the best choice to play Dumbledore, ok? #HPAexposed
This is just ludicrous, but we do stand by Paul DeGeorge’s nutritional advisement. If there’s anybody we can trust in that department, it’s the creator of the Snitchwich. #HPAexposed

We recognize that the moral fabric of a man who hates Batman AND unicorns is potentially questionable, but we stand by our friends. Even if John wants to live forever to maximize his fishing boat proceeds, we’re here for him. But let’s be real: if a Green brother is using dark magic for immortality, it’s totally Hank. Accio Deathly Hallows, anyone? #HPAexposed
story: The Harry Potter Alliance with Cicilia Tara and Nurul Ainiyah.

message: Though Matt will continue as the HPA’s Executive Director, we can now confirm he WILL be filling in as the fifth member of One Direction. But we take issue with Rita’s insinuation that Matt’s plaid shirts landed him the role and ask that she not erase his ent id-ent-ity or the impact this step forward in ent repres-ent-ation will make. #HPAexposed
More outright lies from Rita Skeeter's Quick Quotes Quill. #HPAexposed
Okay, look, that thing in the back of our fridge may look like a long-dead, world-renowned wizard, but it’s actually just a really moldy Snitchwich we forgot to throw out. We promise.
These claims about Darren Criss from Rita Skeeter are absolutely false, but we can neither confirm nor deny the potential existence of a #HedwigLives musical from Team StarKid.

We are shocked and appalled that anybody would spread such terrible lies about one of our board members just because he gets an oil stipend. We’d also like to remind the public that Paul’s departure came down to one thing and one thing only: his realization that his job title was E.D. (the Executive Director) and not, in fact,  E.T. (the Extraterrestrial).
story: The Harry Potter Alliance added 2 new photos.

message: Ok, full disclosure: we DID say this when we were mourning Zayn's departure, but we were JOKING. #HPAexposed
Ok Rita Skeeter, you have officially gone TOO FAR. We would NEVER turn down an invitation to the Derek Zoolander Center For Kids Who Can't Read Good. We are offended. #HPAexposed

Our upcoming annual report will show that our staff consumed a collective 3,125 pounds of Snitchwiches in 2014 so the claim that we were the ones to shut down the Snitchwich operation at LeakyCon is simply ludicrous. Nice try, Skeeter. #HPAexposed

We know this looks bad, what with our slogan and all, but we assure you we only have the best intentions. Besides, if we ever make a physical weapon to harness the power of love, it'll totally be a nerf gun. #HPAexposed

Okay folks, the gig is up. Our legal team wasn’t having luck with the traditional route so they recruited Bugging Expert, Hermione Granger, and… we caught her! Rita Skeeter’s been using her animagus form to spy on us during meetings and at events. Looks like old habits die hard.

We’ll be making sure that Rita Skeeter’s defamatory accusations never see a day in print. Thank you for being patient and having our backs in this rough time. It means a lot to us since we’re already super busy planning for Accio Books, which by the way, kicks off tomorrow.

Here’s hoping it’ll be smooth sailing from here on out. Get those books ready!

Mischief managed.

Our friends at Fight for the Future are organizing a day of action against internet censorship scheduled for tomorrow, April 23. Sign up below to join in.

This is important - and if you use the internet at all, it’s important to you specifically. The architects of the Trans-Pacific Partnership are intent on fast-tracking the massive trade agreement through Congress, probably because they understand that the devil’s in the details and it’s in their best interest to fend off scrutiny.

The Trans-Pacific Partnership would: 1) damage the FCC’s ability to enforce new net neutrality rules, 2) make it easier for telecoms to create prioritized fast lanes for specific content providers, 3) tighten restrictions on fair use of copyrighted materials, potentially harming artistic expression across all social media platforms and content creation hubs - from Facebook to YouTube to Reddit, 4) put more power into the hands of giant corporations, facilitating their avoidance of crucial environmental protocol and basic protections for workers, 5) increase the ability of corporations to fight back against whistleblowers and media entities that expose corporate abuse of power.

And that’s just the tip of the iceberg.

You can help stop this from happening. Join in below.

Love #AccioBooks? National Library Legislative Day kicks off tomorrow! Find out how and why to participate - along with who to call and what to say - here:
National Library Legislative Day begins today! Advocate for libraries by following the instructions and script here:

Today is National Library Legislative Day!

We’re banding together with the American Library Association to protect the things we hold dear: libraries, communities, and the power of stories. We even have wizard activist representatives on-site at Capitol Hill. Here’s how you can do your part from home:

- Check out our handy script and the asks online. (https://drive.google.com/file/d/0BzUCAywi1eQDUHRzMzNERzlIajQ/view)
- Visit contactingthecongress.org and enter your address to get your senators and representative’s phone numbers.
- Call them up and read the script, or share the message in your own words.
- Amplify the message: send them an email or tweet them using the hashtag #nlld.

That’s it! You’ve got the power, the imagination, and the absolute awesomeness to do this. The weapon we have is love. Go show Congress how to use it.

message: Tales of Chapters seeks to promote sharing the stories we grew up with. While it's safe to say many of us grew up reading Harry Potter, there are other important stories we never get to hear about. Ron Weasley had never heard of Cinderella, and Hermione had never heard of Babbity Rabbity and the Cackling Stump - we know that not everyone has had the opportunity to learn about the stories that are culturally relevant to you. Check out our Chapters' stories, then share yours in the comments!

Help us write community guidelines as part of our upcoming Positive Fandom campaign: http://bit.ly/positivefandom

We’ve been gearing up to make this a summer of healthy, positive fandom. We have several campaigns, events, and activities coming up that will revolve around celebrating and improving the communities we live in.

As part of our upcoming Positive Fandom campaign, we want to establish some guidelines about how to be part of these communities and how to approach different situations. Our senior staff put together an initial draft that was then edited by our volunteer staff, Uplift, and some of our partners. Because we think everyone in the community should have a say in how it’s led, we want to open up the editing process to you, too.

Please have a look and let us know what you think in the Google doc! We’ll have it open for comments and suggestions through June 25th.
Nobody tell Hagrid about Jurassic World. It's not going to end well. Don't do it.

Join us in our new Fan Works are Fair Use campaign by sharing your #FanWorksTaughtMe story!

Fandom is something very close to our hearts - not just because of what it celebrates, but because of what it creates. From fanfiction to fanart, fanworks mean that canon is only ever the beginning. Even when a series is ongoing, fans create art that fills in holes and bridges gaps, often adding layers and diversity where they’re needed most.

Like all great and powerful things, though, there are people who take issue with it. We want to fight for fanworks, and we want to do it with you.

Starting right now you can visit fanworksarefairuse.org, where we’ll be working together to make sure that any upcoming copyright and trademark laws are ones that protect and support your reimagining of beloved stories. Whether you create them or consume them, then you know better than anyone that fanworks are valuable and deserves a community to protect it.

We also want to celebrate what fanworks have done for us and our friends where the whole world can see it. You can join in by using the hashtag #FanWorksTaughtMe. Here are some examples:

- #FanWorksTaughtMe to think critically about my identity and how that is (or isn’t) reflected in the media.
- I made some of my closest friends through beta-ing fanfiction. #FanWorksTaughtMe
- #FanWorksTaughtMe to step out of my shell by cosplaying at cons.

It’s time to show the world that your creations and and the work you love matter. We can’t wait to hear from you!

#BlackLivesMatter

Our hearts are with those affected by the Charleston shooting: the victims, their loved ones, the people at home who have seen this unfold time and time again. We send all of you love and light.

We would love to tack on a “stay safe” for all those shaken in the wake of this attack, but this is another in a long list of jarring reminders that safety is not simple and not always attainable. No life should ever be taken, but attacks in safe spaces like churches are uniquely harrowing.

It is not on you to stay safe. It is on those who make you fear for your safety to stop doing so. It is on all of us to do our part to make safety a given instead of an unrealistic platitude.

So we will say this: we are thinking of you. We are hoping you are safe. We stand with you. We urge you to come together and draw strength from each other.

For those of us who live outside this fear: it is vital that we stay informed, stay supportive, and do what we can to spread the word. This act of terrorism is symptomatic of problems embedded deeply into our society, and our awareness of that and commitment to dismantle institutionalized racism must be as present in the discussion as our mourning. We must amplify voices, raise awareness, and dig our heels in to work towards a time where this is unthinkable instead of expected.

The weapon we have is love.
The #FanWorksTaughtMe discussion is full of power and positivity! Check it out and share your story. Don't forget to visit the website: http://fanworksarefairuse.org

A co-founder of the Harry Potter Alliance, Andrew has served as our Executive Director and President. Today, he’s announcing his departure as an HPA employee with this message:

“Dear fellow members of the Harry Potter Alliance,

In the wake of our Not In Harry’s Name chocolate frog victory with Warner Bros., I was in Iceland. Iceland is a magical place where they believe in elves (and as such, are more respectful of the environment, not wanting to destroy the homes of any elves). As I was trekking in this otherworldly landscape at the ends of the earth, peering into the heart of magnificent glaciers that are tragically melting, something dawned on me:

I need to stay both a leader and board member of the HPA. But after ten years, I need to leave the payroll as an employee.

If the HPA is the Dumbledore’s Army of our world, then it is time for me to create our own Order of the Phoenix. Doing so will allow the HPA to truly transform the world by imagining better.

Standing in Iceland, peering into the heart of that magical country, I knew in my heart what needed to happen. And like magic, Micah Sirfry - a mentor of mine - offered me a job at his new one-of-a-kind Civic Hall upon my return to the United States. Pretty incredible coincidence! I am going to be Civic Hall’s first fellow in Civic Imagination.

My task, essentially, is to continue working with the HPA on campaigns like Odds In Our Favor and to start entirely new campaigns, including a forthcoming campaign on Star Wars to get the Empire that is Big Money to no longer aim its Death Star at democracy. And there’s more: by 2016, we’ll be announcing programs like Imagine Better Learning that seek to reinvent education in a way that is centered on the imagination. For more, please go here.

So while leaving the employ of the HPA, I am in no way leaving the community. And I’m leaving knowing that our Executive Director Matt Maggiacomo, the other members of our Senior Staff, our volunteer staff, our over 250 chapters in 30 countries, and our members - Wizard Activists like you - will carry this torch together. That in dark and difficult times we will continue to choose what is right over what is easy, continue to approach fantasy not as an escape from our world but as an invitation to go deeper into it, and continue to realize that we are the eighth book. And - as the eighth book - that we will strive to remember that our job is not to save the world, but to fall in love with it.

As we do, there will be more victories like Not In Harry’s Name. As we do, all of us on this precious planet will come together and embrace the notion that the human race does not need to have a tragic ending to our story. Instead, we get to choose our next adventure.

And while it feels dramatic to no longer be on the payroll of the HPA, it’s more of a technicality than anything else. I look forward to more adventures together as we work to destroy every one of our world’s most intractable horcruxes in the name of justice, magic, and - most of all - love.

Until then, after ten years, it’s pretty fun to say mischief managed. And yet, at the same time, to not be truly leaving you but joining you… to still being up to no good.

Thank you for ten years of wonderment, friendship, and social change. Here’s to ten more!

The Weapon We Have Is Love,

Andrew Slack

Harry Potter Alliance - Creator, Cofounder, Board member”

#FlashbackFriday to ten years ago! Remember that time we started a global wizard activist organization?

In 2005, Andrew Slack had a wild idea: what if we could harness the passion of fandom into creating social change? Ten years later, we can confidently say we’re doing just that. To celebrate this milestone, we’re taking ten weeks to look at the incredible ways that the HPA has helped turn fans into heroes.

The road to wizard activism has been filled with twists and turns and from now until our birthday on October 10th, we’ll be exploring this awesome journey with you. Each week, we’ll look back at a year in HPA history. Follow along on our roadmap and see where ten years of wizard activism has led us!

The HPA was just an ickle firstie in 2005, but we were already doing big things. In May, we had our first social media page (on MySpace), and its popularity led Andrew, along with his comedy partner Seth Soulstein and Paul DeGeorge of Harry and the Potters, to begin sketching out a formal plan for the HPA. By October, we were hosting our first wizard rock concert to raise money for Amnesty International. The annual Yule Ball later that year served as the HPA’s first fundraiser, and the first of many celebrations to come.

We’ll be sharing even more throwbacks over the next ten weeks as we lead up to our tenth anniversary on October 10th. And if you want to help us continue kicking butt for another ten years, you can donate $10 - one for each year of awesome - at http://thehpalliance.org/donate. This milestone would not have been possible without your support. Thank you.

message:
How have fan works - from fanfiction to fanart and beyond - impacted your life? Here's part of our friend Lauren Fairweather's answer from her Love For Fanworks video with Kristina Horner:

"When I started writing fanfiction and when I started recording my own wizard rock music, I was kind of a broken version of myself hidden in this shell - I was terrified to really be who I was. Online, I could be who I knew I was on the inside and who I was just terrified to show to everyone else. So a lot of my high school career involved trying to fit in with everybody and then going home and needing that online time - that creative time - to sort of be me again. I noticed that I stopped worrying what people thought about me and that I would rather have people not like it or not understand it than having to hide it from everyone."

Watch the full video at https://youtu.be/O98Gqy0QwEE, then share your fan works story in the comments or with #FanWorksTaughtMe and join us in standing up for fan works by signing up at http://fanworksarefairuse.org!

We are devastated by the circumstances and conditions surrounding the Syrian refugee crisis. The heartbreaking images that have been spread across the internet represent a handful of stories out of millions. When faced with these truths, problems can seem larger than life and certainly too large for us to know how to help. As always, though, there is incredibly strength in numbers. Thousands of people - including many young adult authors - have rallied around Patrick Ness's fundraising efforts benefitting Save the Children. Hundreds of thousands of dollars have been raised already, with most donations being matched.

If you are looking for ways to help, donating to and/or spreading the word about this effort is a fantastic option.

The weapon we have is love.

"I think the reason the world reacted so viscerally to that image of that dead boy on the beach is that - instinctively - we all knew that his blood was on all of our hands. We have legal obligations to refugees under international law, but we also have ethical obligations to them because they are our people."

John's vlogbrothers video for the week is a deeply important one. We urge everyone to watch, share, and do what they can to support refugees. Additional resources are listed in the video description.
NA

message:
It's been an incredible ten years for the HPA. Join us in our next adventure at hpa10.com - this Dumbledore's Army needs your help.

Ten is a big number.

When Harry Potter was ten, he was about to receive the letter that would change his life. The Tenth Doctor took the universe by storm with the power of story. And this October marks ten years of the Harry Potter Alliance.

We’re eagerly inviting you to celebrate with us by supporting our tenth anniversary fundraiser, which launches today.

As we’ve approached this milestone, we’ve spent lots of time looking back at what we’ve done in the past ten years thanks to this community’s generosity and commitment to decreasing worldsuck. The HPA has gone from cofounder Andrew Slack’s wild idea to an organization with countless accomplishments - ones like sending five planes full of supplies to Haiti in the wake of the 2010 earthquake, collecting hundreds of thousands of books for underserved communities, creating over 250 chapters across six continents and 30 countries, getting Warner Bros. to stop using chocolate sourced from child slavery in its Harry Potter products and so much more.

Mostly, though, we’re looking to the future. Not just because we’ll finally have the hoverboards we were promised by movies, but because we know we have more possibilities ahead of us than ever.

When we were just starting out back in 2005, we couldn’t have imagined what the next decade would hold. We had big plans and a bigger drive, but none of it could hold a candle to reality. Now, in 2015, that hasn’t changed.

Going forward, some of our plans look like this: We will continue our annual Accio Books campaign until we’ve raised one million books and built 25 libraries across the world. We will renew our commitment to the LGBTQIA+ community with a campaign to support trans rights and fight individual and government-sanctioned bullying. We will work with our friends at Uplift to grow our Positive Fandom movement and improve fandom spaces for women, LGBTQIA+ communities, people of color, disabled people, and other populations that have been marginalized in conventional fandom spaces. We will soon launch the third and final phase of Odds in Our Favor, which will focus on amplifying the voices of a diverse set of communities impacted by economic inequality. We will grow Granger Leadership Academy into a large-scale fan activist training ground that will revolutionize leadership development. We will continue to transform fandom into a space for social good, individual empowerment, and community-wide collaboration.

As with our first ten years, the next ten years of the HPA will only be possible because of you: your support, your enthusiasm, and your donations. The HPA10 fundraiser is our way of kicking off the next decade.

Your support is especially helpful in the fundraiser’s early days, so please donate and spread the word today and join us for our launch livestream tonight!

Here’s to ten years and loads more.

message:
BIG NEWS: Hermione Granger and Luna Lovegood have announced their run for presidency! Show your support with the Granger/Lovegood 2016 bundle available only at hpa10.com

Read the press release: 

Hermione Granger, Luna Lovegood Announce Entrance Into 2016 Presidential Race

Providence, Rhode Island - Are you ready for Hermione? If not, you might want to begin preparing yourself for the greatest political coup of all time. 

At a press conference held on the front steps of Brown University’s student center, Hermione Granger announced her candidacy for President of the United States of America. 

“I am running for witches,” she proclaimed. “I am running for muggle women. I am running for all oppressed peoples and magical creatures. I am running because you deserve a candidate who’ll buck politics as usual and bring a little more magic to the White House.”

In a legitimate first for any political campaign, Granger went on to provide extensive details regarding her policy positions, as well as concrete plans for achieving her goals. Granger was less specific when asked about how she’s eligible for the United States presidency without being a US Citizen. 

“I found a loophole,” she said enigmatically before changing the subject. “You can read more about my campaign by creating an account on my app, Grangr. All the wizard kids are using it.” 

Granger also took a moment to plug her campaign’s merchandise, which is being sold exclusively in a bundle via the Harry Potter Alliance’s 10th anniversary fundraiser at HPA10.com. The bundle includes a Granger/Lovegood 2016 t-shirt, a campaign sign, an iron-on patch, and a Ready for Hermione bumper sticker.

Granger was joined by running mate Luna Lovegood, who became distracted mid-announcement when she claimed a horse-mounted university cop was a thestral. She grabbed the microphone from Granger and asked if anyone else could see it. When everyone responded that they could, in fact, see the police horse, she began hugging everyone in the audience and expressing sympathy for their losses.

“I guess awkward sympathy hugs are the new baby hugs,” muttered Granger under her breath.

Many campus groups showed up in support of Granger’s announcement, but none were as boisterous and enthusiastic as Brown University’s Feminist Majority. Members of the group held up signs reading Granger Is Our Queen and Trample Deez Nuts -- either a reference to the mysterious candidate currently polling at 9% in North Carolina or a jab at the patriarchy in general.

You can find out more about the magical progressive movement at HPA10.com.

message:
We are stunned and saddened by the tragic passing of Jake Brewer, an extraordinary civic leader, activist, visionary, photographer, triathlete, friend, husband, and father. 

Jake was hit by oncoming traffic while participating in a charity bike ride in support of a friend with cancer. He leaves behind his wife Mary Katharine Ham, their daughter Georgia, and a baby on the way. We are sending all of our love to his family in this unthinkably difficult time.

Jake had recently left his post as the head of global policy and external affairs at Change.Org to work as the Senior Technology Advisor at the White House. His resume spans far longer and more impressively than most thirty-four year olds’ and he was often behind the scenes of profound moments we all know - most recently he helped ensure fourteen year-old Ahmed Mohamed’s story was heard around the nation.

Jake was a friend, collaborator, and mentor to many in the Harry Potter Alliance. He did everything he could to get the HPA's name out there and he truly believed in us. While working as the strategic communications director for U.S. Ignite and as a partner of the new media firm Fission Strategy, Jake co-founded Define American with his best friend, Jose Antonio Vargas. Define American strives to shift the narrative surrounding immigration and has been the HPA’s leading partner in our immigration work over the years. Jake was instrumental in orchestrating our Superman Is An Immigrant campaign and was one of the unseen players advising our team when our volunteer staffer Julian Gomez publicly came out as undocumented. 

Far beyond his accomplishments, Jake was a brilliant, compassionate, energetic, and loving individual. He truly lit up any room he was in with his humor and authenticity. To leave the way he did - biking in a charity race - is an almost fitting, though tragic, conclusion to his brief life. He left while doing something he loved in support of others.

Speaking on Jake’s passing, President Obama said “I am heartbroken… Simply put, Jake was one of the best.” The world will be a different place without Jake Brewer, but we are privileged to have been a part of it with him for the short time that we were.

Please join us in remembering Jake and sending love to his family, friends, and the millions of people whom he impacted. If you would like to help, you can donate to the memorial education fund set up for his children: https://www.gofundme.com/p54ggr8g

All photo credit to Mary Katharine Ham: instagram.com/mkhammertime

message:
Our hearts go out to all those affected by today's shooting in Oregon: to the victims, their loved ones, and anyone shaken by this all-too-familiar tragedy.

Shootings should be unthinkable, not expected. We must prioritize and protect human lives, not that designed to end them.

We know it's difficult to feel anything but helplessness in times like these. We know it's difficult to look upon the stark lack of change in the wake of these startlingly frequent tragedies and not feel deeply discouraged. But we cannot become complacent; the stakes are too high to let our world's death eaters win. As we have seen time and time again, change happens because of people who dig their heels in and keep their voices loud and steady even - and especially - when the powerful demand their silence. 

Never underestimate how powerful you are and can be. When the high walls guarding the guilty seem impermeable, our hearts and voices are all we have. Do not let them tell you that this is not enough to move mountains. It always, always will be.

The weapon we have is love.
Christmas dinner at actual Hogwarts? BRB, cramming our entire staff into a flying Ford Anglia.

On October 10th, 2005, the Harry Potter Alliance held its first-ever event in Somerville, Massachusetts. Now, ten years later - and with the support of many people in the NerdCon: Stories community - the HPA has grown to a global organization with accomplishments under its belt such as sending five cargo planes of disaster relief supplies to Haiti, donating over 250,000 books around the world, and getting Warner Bros. to make all Harry Potter chocolate ethically sourced. 

Come celebrate ten years of the HPA using fandom to make the world a better place and learn how to get involved for the next ten. There will be special guests and loads of surprises!

message:
As our tenth birthday approaches, we’re looking more and more towards the next decade. We really are just getting started.

For example: among our many big plans for the next year alone, we will be launching a major campaign to fight institutionalized bullying against trans people.

Marriage equality was a huge victory, but people in LGBTQIA communities need much more. Many LGBTQIA people face legal discrimination in the workplace and in public spaces, often under the guise of religious freedom. We’re happy and humbled to have contributed to the fight for same-sex marriage, but we understand that there is so much more to be done in the fight for equality. 

Earlier this year, our Communications Director and Spokesperson Jackson Bird came out as trans, reaching tens of thousands of people from other trans youth to Eddie Redmayne. Jack’s leadership and perspective will be instrumental as we tackle trans issues.

This trans rights campaign will be our next step in this crucial movement: we will launch a major campaign to fight the legalized discrimination and institutionalized bullying that impacts trans people across the United States and beyond. 

Our current tenth birthday fundraiser will fund our next year of operation; it ends soon and is still aways from its goal. Our work will be impossible without support from our members - that’s anybody reading this post. Donate to HPA10.com and spread the word to help us build a winning campaign for human rights.
We're super close to our hpa10.com goal of $77,777 - we could hit it TODAY with your help! Donate and spread the word so we can unveil our exciting stretch goals!

In 2016, we will launch a Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them campaign dealing with environmental justice and climate change awareness. You can help make it awesome by donating to hpa10.com - there are only a few days left to do just that and snag a perk!

We are so close to the end of our HPA10 fundraiser, and before you know it all those nifty perks you’ve been eyeing will be gone! We can't stop now, though. Now is the time to donate if you haven't already, or ask your friends and family to donate.

Every dollar coming into our campaign will help us kickstart another decade of social change, so you can rest assured that your donation will be put to good use. Whether it’s a $15 wrock comp or a $500 Granger Leadership Academy attendee sponsorship, your contribution will make a difference. 

Can’t donate this year? Already donated everything you can spare? That’s okay! Make sure all your friends, family, and acquaintances are aware of the HPA and what we do, and ask them to donate if they haven’t already. Share why you think the HPA is worth investing in. Maybe it’s the way we turn fans into heroes, or how our chapters are transforming cities with their community-driven projects. We’re a global Dumbledore’s Army, and we need help if we’re going to defeat the world’s horcruxes!

There's only two and half hours left of our HPA10 fundraiser, let's finish strong. Help us meet our $115,000 stretch goal.
HPA10 ends in just ONE HOUR. This is your last call for all of our exclusive perks, which go away at the end of the fundraiser! Head to HPA10.com and grab them now!

HPA10 has come to a successful end! Thank you so much to everyone who donated and spread the word about the campaign. None of this would have been possible without you. We know we're about to enter a second decade that will be even stronger than the first, and it's entirely because of all of the generous support you've given us this last month. We can't wait for you all to see what we have in store for 2016. Thank you again, and remember, the weapon we have is love. ❤️⚡️

message:
We’re celebrating Indigenous People’s Day in affirmation of what should be self-evident: much of what we know and enjoy has been made possible by atrocities committed against others. In order to truly move forward, we must acknowledge these crimes and make whatever reparations are possible.

Christopher Columbus’ “discovery” of America was followed by the genocide and enslavement of tens of millions of native people. His actions led to the transatlantic slave trade and centuries of violence and discrimination towards indigenous people.

We applaud those cities that have made the recent shift away from Columbus Day, as well as Berkeley for first making the change in the early nineties. It is our hope that these are the first of many. Please join us in celebrating Indigenous People’s Day and moving towards a more honest, inclusive future.
We're celebrating Spirit Day in solidarity with those who face bullying based on their sexuality and/or gender. Please join us in learning more and spreading the word!

Join the revolution. Share your story now: myhungergames.org

Last year, you showed us that economic inequality isn’t a theme from the dystopian future - it’s a system we’re all living in. When Peacekeepers beat civilians in the streets, we recognize that Panem isn’t just a vision of some distant future. When the mayor of District 12 tells of a world ravaged by climate change, we know it’s more than a story on a page.  When Katniss struggles with PTSD without adequate resources, it’s a reflection of the problems we’re already facing. The effects of economic inequality are everywhere, from our homes and neighborhoods to the furthest corners of the world.

But the Hunger Games didn’t just hold a mirror to the worst of our world. It championed rebellion and revolution. It reminded us that big change is possible - that it only happens when we act on our power.

Katniss Everdeen struggled with economic inequality and seemingly impossible odds, but she never gave up. When she got the chance to fight back, she encouraged the whole world to join her. We recognize that same heroism in you. For the past two years, we’ve worked to create discussion and change around economic inequality through our Odds In Our Favor campaign. Now, as the final Hunger Games movie approaches, we’re going bigger than ever before. Are you in?

We want to hear your full #MyHungerGames stories: your real life struggles with inequality, and how you're fighting back. We’ll be sharing your stories on myhungergames.org.

We've also partnered with a coalition of rebel organizations who are all taking action to end economic inequality. Whether you're passionate about mental health, climate change, prison reform, racial justice, or more, we have tons of actions to help you dive in, make a difference, and join the revolution. 

The Hunger Games movies may be ending, but the story we're writing - the story of a more just and equal world - continues. Help us write it - until the odds are in everyone’s favor.
story: The Harry Potter Alliance updated their cover photo.

message:
A message from our Executive Director regarding devastating news from the Harry Potter community:

Today, the Harry Potter fandom is mourning the loss of one of our most dedicated members, Dante Salvatierra, who passed away after a long battle with brain cancer.

About a year ago, Dante posted the following on facebook:

“Today might be the day they tell me that I only have x months on Earth. They don’t know that I love math and that x can mean anything. They also don’t know that my middle name means warrior. My last means save the earth. Not finished with this war. Not done saving your asses.”

I couldn’t possibly produce words that better exemplify who Dante was and the incredible personality and heart that he shared with the world around him. Dante exemplified what the wizard rock community is all about: he was exceedingly generous, his enthusiasm was boundless, and he was unwaveringly kind. He traveled great distances to attend wizard rock shows and Harry Potter conferences. He put himself out to organize shows when bands came through Omaha. He threw his full support behind every band that took the stage, no matter how big or small. He danced through every set and his joy lit up the room.

When events become legendary within a community, most of the credit is given to the performers and the organizers – but it’s the fans who truly make these events amazing and life-altering for everyone involved. I can’t think about events like Wrockstock and Hallows & Horcruxes without thinking of Dante. Fans like him were the heart and soul of those concerts. His presence and attitude made us all feel more at home and inspired us to treat each other with kindness and respect. Dante embodied the spirit and values of positive fandom, and in doing so he made our fandom a better place.

I am so grateful for you, Dante, and I wish you the best of luck in your next big adventure.

May we all aspire to be a little more like you.

Love,

Matt Maggiacomo
Executive Director
The Harry Potter Alliance
Come hang out with fellow wizard activists and HPA Communications Director Jackson Bird at Olan Rogers' exquisite Soda Parlor.

message:
Just as the children of Panem are thrown into the Hunger Games while adults are safe, many youth are jailed for nonviolent offenses that would not be considered criminal if they were adults. The United States incarcerates children at a higher rate than any other developed nation. Many of these young people will spend time in solitary confinement, where they are denied human contact, fresh air, and more.

In Panem, many teens spend their time in the arena alone, fearful and in need of aid. Those that survive deal with PTSD, depression, anxiety and other forms of mental illness. Yet, for 74 years, no one spoke up. We CAN speak up for the seventy percent of children behind bars in our world struggling with mental health. We can decrease that number by fighting for youth justice.

Fusion and their Prison Kids documentary is taking a small first step by working to ban solitary confinement for minors. You can sign their petition and learn more by watching the documentary here: http://fusion.net/series/prison-kids/

Want to tell your #MyHungerGames story? Submit your own post here: http://myhungergames.org

Jabriera’s #MyHungerGames story is about dealing with oppression and advocating for change.  

Jabriera grew up in Baltimore, Maryland. When she was 16, she got into an argument with her grandmother. As Jabriera’s grandmother was disciplining her, Jabriera tried to get her off her. Jabriera left the house, and later that day her grandmother died of a heart attack because of the argument. She was tried as an adult for second degree murder, second degree assault and first degree assault. When she went to court for a hearing, she was two days away from turning 18, so she plead guilty to the charges for fear of the trial dragging out longer and her punishment being worse. She was taken to a juvenile facility initially where she received resources such as education, group time, and mental health help. This was short lived however. She later was taken to an adult facility where she had to shower with women twice her age and was shamelessly exposed to a squat and cough in front of everyone while menstruating. She was placed on lockdown three times, once for misconduct, once with no reason, and the last time was because of a fight. The last lockdown was supposed to last two weeks but ended up being 36 days. When in lockdown, there was no contact with prison staff, only being housed in the same area as other inmates.

When she was released she was denied many opportunities. She asked for vouchers for food and services that other inmates receive upon release, but she was denied those too because felons don’t receive them. She wanted to attend University of Baltimore College, but was automatically rejected due to her felony charges. She had no place to stay. Then she met the Just Kids Maryland Campaign who assisted her and worked to get her record expunged. Now she works with Just Kids as an Assistant Youth Organizer where she has been working for four years. Now she works to share the stories of other youth such as herself because she knows too well that the issue of youth incarcerated as adults needs to be addressed. While also being a single mother of a 2-year old, she has been a mentor to youth and has been an advocate and a catalyst for change.

Want to make a stand during Youth Justice Awareness Month (October)? Show your Hands of Support. Take a photo of your three-finger salute with #YJAM or some other short message of support for youth justice, and share it on social media with the #YJAM hashtag. Then, visit OddsinOurFavor.org to learn how to do more.

We can change the Pine Ridge Reservation's #MyHungerGames story. Some words from the Thunder Valley Community Development Corporation:

"Each generation of Native youth has had the “odds stacked against them.” Those challenges look different for each passing generation, yet they share common threads. Our lands, water and families are still at risk from a value and development system that is very different from the traditions tribal community call their own.

We know ourselves to be of the land, not conquerors of it. We know that water is not infinite and not something to own, but should be protected as one would protect and love the eldest matriarch of one’s own family. The strength and quality of our character and the acts of good towards others are the currency our people use. While governments and others try to buy our land and sell our culture, no amount of money can take away our integrity—we are resilient and we will continue to work for our people and for the Earth.

The young people in our programs at Thunder Valley Community Development Corporation, where I work on the Pine Ridge Indian Reservation in South Dakota, show great courage. Some of our young people are taking important risks and uplifting themselves so that they can uplift others improve the quality of life for all. They are involved in internships, skills building, and moving our people along on a pathway out of poverty.

The way we see it, by empowering young people to direct their own future; by building capacity locally; by addressing the worlds biggest social, environmental and economic issues and disparities in one of the most significant places of struggle; we are disrupting the status quo and overcoming the negative statistics that big media companies like to use to sell their papers. We have survived colonization, genocide and we will continue to not only survive, but thrive. This represents the true culture of Lakota people.

Do not be fooled by the media or by the history books, the movement is here and the time is now. We need allies who see the truth and to partner with us in the face of adversity as we forge our own, bright future."

Support the work of changemakers in the Lakota Community: Share the video about Pine Ridge Reservation’s #RegenerativeCommunity on social media (https://www.youtube.com/watch?t=7&v=-6aBQ09SjNI), then share your #MyHungerGames story.

In two weeks, we’ll be watching Mockingjay, Part 2, the last film in The Hunger Games franchise. But we want the world to know what you know - that the revolution is just beginning. At MyHungerGames.org, we’ve been sharing stories of rebels who are fighting for change in their communities. These rebels are working in communities around the world and now, they need you.             

Don’t tell the Capitol, but we’re recruiting an elite group of rebels to share the stories of the revolution and complete an important mission for District 13. We’re looking for rebels who want to change the world - and we think that might be you.

If you sign up with District 13, you’ll receive instructions via electronic transmissions outlining your role in the resistance and inviting you to join us in finding and sharing messages that are hidden all over the internet. We’ll even be hosting a secret broadcast on Tuesday the 17th of November at 8:00 pm EST, where you can opt in to be briefed on tactics for the campaign.

The Hunger Games film franchise has never been about our hunger games.

After using a story about inequality to sell makeup, high-end cars, and even sandwiches, marketers have released their worst idea yet: a Hunger Games theme park. 

What could a theme park of a dystopian world possibly look like? We have some ideas…                           

    - Ride the Student Debt Rollercoaster: it just keeps going up!                   
    - A carnival-style Guess Your Salary! game where the staff always know to guess 25% less for women.          
    - No need for a First Aid Station, sick park goers can just ignore it and hope it goes away!
    - Citizens with papers, enjoy your complimentary Fast Passes! Undocumented immigrants and refugees, please form an unending queue outside the gates.

Got more theme park suggestions for Lionsgate? Let's hear them! Post them here or on twitter using the #MyHungerGames tag or submit them to MyHungerGames.Org 

We don’t need a Hunger Games theme park because, in many ways, we already live in Panem. This is our reality. Let's tell Lionsgate loud and clear: we don't want to build a theme park. We want to build a movement.

In the United States, it's estimated that 49,933 veterans are homeless on any given night. When veterans return home, they often cope with a multitude of issues: PTSD, substance abuse, a lack of family and social support networks, trouble transferring military training and skills to the civilian workforce, and more.

Veterans, like all people, deserve to have the odds in their favor. Some states, like Virginia, are working to end veteran homelessness by 2017. Visit the National Coalition for Homeless Veterans to find out how to help in your community: http://nchv.org/index.php/getinvolved/getinvolved/how_you_can_help/

This weekend, we're introducing you to our incredible Granger Leadership Academy keynote speakers. First up: Meghan Tonjes.

Meghan would give any so-called Renaissance man a run for his money. Whether she’s performing gorgeous original music, recording breathtaking covers, speaking difficult truths in honest videos, calling injustices for what they are, laying down the law 140 characters at a time, or leading body positivity movements (#BootyRevolution), Meghan kills it time after time. Her bold wisdom empowers people - from her regular viewers and the communities she’s a part of to readers of the countless international publications that have covered her work - every day.

We’re thrilled to welcome her to the Granger Leadership Academy this March. Between her online voice and her game-changing presence on panels at events like GeekyCon and VidCon, we already know she’ll have incredible things to say.

GLA is a place for people like Meghan, whether they’re accomplished professionals or young students. We welcome your voice, no matter how small or how loud, and we can’t wait to show you how far it can go.

GLA will take place on March 3rd-6th 2016 in Warwick, Rhode Island. If you’d like to attend, you can register and book your hotel rooms at http://grangerleadershipacademy.com
Paris: we are thinking of you and hoping for your safety. The weapon we have is love. ❤️⚡️

We are with you: processing, grieving, baffled, shattered, grasping desperately for light.

Here is what we know: unspeakable harm was done to Paris tonight; unspeakable harm will be done to people of Muslim faith and people of color by people who take advantage of tragedy to act on their hatred; people across the world - ourselves among them - are shaken to their very core; this is not the first time; we cannot say it will be the last time.

And so much of this feels intensely personal.

It seems that the list of safe spaces torn apart by violence grows every year: schools, movie theaters, schools again, places of worship, places of community, venues for live music. We grow up hearing that stories are escapes only to find demons in our safest havens.

And so we cannot blame those whose lists of personal safe spaces narrow in parallel. Your feelings are valid, your reaction is valid, and we urge you to follow your gut, to seek what safety means for you.

But if you feel safest in the very places terrorists - in Paris, in Columbine, in Aurora, in Newton, in Charleston, and on and on and on - have devastated, know you have not lost them. If anger boils in your stomach, know nothing can come from meeting their hatred with your own. The most powerful thing we can do every time we move forward from unthinkable loss is to hold on to love and to hold on to what we love.

This is not easy. But it is so important.

The places we love - movie theaters at midnight, libraries where books changed our lives, venues where we sang late into the night - have given us not just entertainment, but spaces to make sense of the world, spaces to make sense of ourselves, crowds to be distinctly and lastingly unalone in, lifelong friendships, lifelong magic, homes to carry with us.

We cannot and will not let them take any of this from us.

Here is how we move forward: keep loving; keep fighting; celebrate story; laugh, dance, sing - with your friends, with strangers, with every single person who keeps showing up when the world tells them not to; resist hatred; resist cynicism; know none of this is foolish; know that it is necessary; protect and defend those who - not for the first time - will be victims of hatred falsely carried out in the name of justice; give love and light to those around you and those around the world; be excellent to each other; be good.

Always, always, always: the weapon we have is love.

Like the workers in the districts, Walmart associates are going hungry while in the Capitol, the Waltons and their heirs are getting rich. Now and through Black Friday, Walmart workers across the country are driving this point home by fasting for fair pay. Show your support for workers by tweeting and posting about #fastfor15 and check out local events at www.protests.blackfriday.

“We need $15 an hour and full-time hours to provide for our families,” said Jasmine Dixon, a Walmart associate and a mother of two boys from Denver, Colorado.“I’m a single mother of two young boys, Zion who is one, and Isaiah who is three. Struggling to find ways to feed them everyday is hard. I’ve had to forego meals just so my boys would have enough to eat. Too many times, I have had to go to food banks just to try and scrape up some rice and beans for my kids to eat. If it weren’t for food stamps and government programs for my kids, I don’t know what I would do. Even worse, I’ve seen Walmart throw away food everyday, all the time. If they gave Walmart associates that food it would go such a long way. My situation is no different than the hundreds of thousands of other working moms at Walmart.”

Like so many others, 34-year-old Jihan was willing to risk everything in order to escape war-torn Syria and find safety for her family. Unlike most, she is blind.

The tragedies in Paris and Lebanon put refugees in extra danger of violence and deportation - when violence is exactly why they left. If you live in the U.S., contact your lawmakers to let them know that you welcome refugees in your community.

Join Avaaz's movement of solidarity with France, Lebanon, and people like Jihan: https://secure.avaaz.org/en/paris_solidarity/

The Granger Leadership Academy is an experience like none other.

The Harry Potter Alliance’s fan activist con will take place this spring. We spoke to conference organizer and all-around badass Janae Phillips about what makes it different and - yes - magical:

HPA: What is GLA? 

JP: GLA is a training ground for our world’s heroes. 

The GLA experience takes everything the HPA values - creativity, unironic enthusiasm, the importance of stories, and the power of anyone to become a hero - and wraps it all into an immersive leadership conference.

How has your experience with traditional leadership conferences shaped you? How will GLA be different?

JP: I’m of the opinion that if leadership education is boring you’re doing it so, so wrong. You know when things advertise themselves as a “resume booster” before anything else? Yeah, that means they couldn’t think of a good reason you’d want to do that but they want you to do it anyway. 

I studied leadership programs and was involved in both running and attending a lot of leadership workshops and conferences. I often found myself frustrated with the fact that many traditional formats can feel like hours of lectures, and there was very little attention paid to building an experience out of the event. A lot of times you leave these events not entirely sure how all of that information fit into your own development as a leader. Plus, there was often a disproportionate number of older white males around. 

GLA is built to turn those traditions on their head - to put attendees and their journey in the center of everything we do, to make the experience as fun as a fandom con, and to give the power of mentorship and teaching to a diversity of voices that actually represents our communities.

HPA: What do you hope attendees will come back with?

JP: I hope that they leave GLA feeling like they learned so much more about themselves, feeling empowered to go back to their communities and be leaders, and with a couple new friends.

HPA:You can pull any fictional character out of their respective worlds and bring them to GLA. Which do you choose? Why?

JP: Oh boy. I’d love to hear what Korra would have to say about leadership. She developed and grew so much as a leader herself, I think she’d have a lot to say on the subject. And she’d just be fun to have around.

If you’re interested in GLA, you can learn more and register at grangerleadershipacademy.com!

We can’t wait to see you there.

story: The Harry Potter Alliance with Emil Johan Johansson.

message:
This is what we’re about. The idea that story can change the world is at the heart of what we do and how we do it.

But before we were building an organization, planning campaigns, or sharing in the power of story and the power of love with a community built on both, we were reading and watching Harry Potter. We were being enchanted by actors like Alan Rickman, who brought our very favorite story to life with incomparable commitment and skill. To think about the films is to think about that inimitable sneer, that drawl nobody can ever unhear.

Those performances and their impact never faded. In the past month alone, we’ve seen references to Alan Rickman’s Snape in puppet shows and lyrics, from Yule Balls to Draco and the Malfoys’ house show. And in the years before that? Too many good times to count. We don’t think Alan could possibly know exactly how many or exactly how grateful we are.

The truest thing Severus Snape ever said was simple: “It’s real for us.” It all is: the message, the memories, the magic. The best way to move forward is to carry that with us.

If that first potions scene struck fear - or anger - into your heart, if Alan Rickman’s immaculate portrayal made you feel something, to want to do something, to want to be kinder and to never abuse your power over those in your care and to stick it to the man, that was real. It is real. The power of a community coming together in a time of darkness and creating light is real, too. Don’t lose sight of it. Use it to change the world.

story: The Harry Potter Alliance shared Dylan Marron's post.

message:
As we observe Martin Luther King Jr. Day, we must take time to reflect and commit ourselves to progressive, compassionate change.

This holiday is, yes, one to celebrate - a day to consider the triumphs of the Civil Rights movements, the revolutionary contributions of black activists and artists, the story of everything that has led to today. But that cannot be all that it is. We cannot welcome the false sense of achievement we’ve been taught to slip into on the third Monday of every January. To do so would be to discredit the daily demonstrations demanding basic rights, deny the dangerous failings of the system, and diminish the mourning that weighs on communities that have come to know the realities of racism all too well.

We must regard today with solace and solemnity rather than with victory. And we must keep moving forward.

We must listen to firsthand accounts of oppression and marginalization. We must allow these stories to inform our worldview and advocacy. We must advocate vocally, but never speak for or over the people we seek to help. We must speak and act with compassion, conscious of the power and privilege we carry. We must strive to educate ourselves. We must demand equality consistently and completely.

We must do these things in King’s memory, yes, but also in Mike Brown’s, in Tamir Rice’s, in Sandra Bland's - the list, to our great sorrow, goes on. And we must do these things with the urgent hope that together we can shift the tides and create a tomorrow where this is no longer our normal.

In his book recounting the Montgomery bus boycott, King wrote: “Human progress is neither automatic nor inevitable. Even a superficial look at history reveals that no social advance rolls in on the wheels inevitability. Every step towards the goal of justice requires sacrifice, suffering, and struggle; the tireless exertions and passionate concern of dedicated individuals. […] This is no time for apathy or complacency. This is a time for vigorous and positive action.”

message: This is a fantastic milestone!

Become a Friend of the Apparating Library; get cool perks; help make the world better with the power of books.

Every year, we go back to basics for our longest running campaign: Accio Books. In the dawning hours of our organization, we built the Harry Potter Alliance on the idea that story and the people who believe in it can change the world. For over ten years, this has remained the foundation of everything we do.

We know story is powerful, so it follows that we believe story should be accessible. Through Accio Books, our global community comes together to celebrate story, fight for literary access, and collect books which are then distributed to underserved populations. Our sixth Accio Books campaign is just around the corner – we can’t wait.

But first, we need your help.

Today, our second Friends of the Apparating Library fundraiser kicks off.

The money raised will allow us to coordinate a book drive spanning several continents, provide essential resources to our members and chapters, support events in honor of World Book Night in three cities, advocate to Congress for increased support for public libraries, and build a brand new library in Masaka, Uganda.
The Apparating Library needs your help: apparatinglibrary.org

It includes dubious and/or delicious recipes from authors like Laurie Halse Anderson, Hank Green, Mara Wilson Writes Stuff, John Scalzi, NaNoWriMo, Lev Grossman, Dave Roman, Sarah McCarry, Mercedes Lackey, and more! It also includes a one-year Friends of the Apparating Library membership, getting you into the most magical bookclub this side of Hogwarts.

You'll also be supporting our literacy efforts and helping our Masaka chapter build a library. Magic is real.
Grab your Granger/Lovegood 2016 canvassing kit while you still can. Help change the world w/ books while doing it. Only at apparatinglibrary.org!
For the magical surfaces in your life. Only at appararinglibrary.org for a few more days!

One of the most powerful things about Accio Books and the Apparating Library is that they expose people to books they might not otherwise have access to - books with a wide range of representations and experiences. Through these books, people can better understand the world around them and, often, themselves.

Representation is so vital to helping us figure out our identities and how we want to exist in the world. Today, we’re celebrating Transgender Day of Visibility, so we want to share some of our favorite trans narratives from the Apparating Library. Check out Rethinking Normal by Katie Rain Hill, George by Alex Gino's, and Redefining Realness by Janet Mock. Let us know which books have helped you!

Support our work to get these and other stories into the hands of readers who need them by donating at appratinglibrary.org.

The HPA is up to so much that it’s hard to believe we don’t have a timeturner. Because we know that it can be tough to keep up with all those magical happenings, we created the Wizard Activist News Dispatch (the WAND for short). By subscribing, you get a full year of features on our campaigns, spotlights on the chapters and volunteers who make our work possible, and all the goofy exclusives you could ask for (like wizard horoscopes and cut-out wizard emojis). It’s Ollivander approved -- subscribe to the WAND today!

This year at GeekyCon, we’re doing a special art project that YOU can be part of - even if you’re not in Orlando. As part of #Protego, we’re creating a scrapbook of supportive messages and artwork for trans and non-binary young people.  This community scrapbook will be donated, along with leftover books from the Apparating Library, to the Orlando Youth Alliance, which serves LGBTQ+ youth in the Orlando area.  

To participate, send your supportive messages and/or artwork to info@thehpalliance.org by Sunday at 12pm EST. Messages can be typed or handwritten. Artwork of all kinds, from doodles to photos to epic masterpieces, will be accepted.  Help us let trans teens know there is a whole community of people who love you for who you are.

Thinking about joining us at the Granger Leadership Academy in 2017? What about leading with us? 

We have an open call for programs, which could include discussion panels, round tables, skills trainings, self care workshops, demonstrations of artistic and creative ideas, and more! Submissions are due September 6th, so be like Hermione - head to the library (or your favorite spot), get planning, and submit your ideas at bit.ly/GLASubmissions
